<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Indicate by check mark whether the registrants (1)&nbsp;have filed all reports required to be filed
by Section&nbsp;13 or </I><I>15(d)</I><I> of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 during the preceding 12&nbsp;months (or
for such shorter period that the registrants were required to file such reports), and (2)&nbsp;have been
subject to such filing requirements for the past 90&nbsp;days. Yes
<FONT face="Wingdings">&#254;</FONT>  No
<FONT face="Wingdings">&#111;</FONT> Indicate by check
mark whether the registrant is an accelerated filer (as defined by Rule&nbsp;12b-2 of the Securities
Exchange Act of 1934).</I>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This combined Form 10-Q is separately filed by The Southern Company, Alabama Power Company,
Georgia Power Company, Gulf Power Company, Mississippi Power Company, Savannah Electric and Power
Company, and Southern Power Company. Information contained herein relating to any individual
company is filed by such company on its own behalf. Each company makes no representation as to
information relating to the other companies.

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>CAUTIONARY STATEMENT REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING INFORMATION</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q contains forward-looking statements. Forward-looking
statements include, among other things, statements concerning the strategic goals for Southern
Company&#146;s wholesale business, retail sales growth, storm damage cost recovery, environmental
regulations and expenditures, financing activities, completion of construction projects, and
estimated construction and other expenditures. In some cases, forward-looking statements can be
identified by terminology such as &#147;may,&#148; &#147;will,&#148; &#147;could,&#148; &#147;should,&#148; &#147;expects,&#148; &#147;plans,&#148;
&#147;anticipates,&#148; &#147;believes,&#148; &#147;estimates,&#148; &#147;projects,&#148; &#147;predicts,&#148; &#147;potential,&#148; or &#147;continue&#148; or the
negative of these terms or other similar terminology. There are various factors that could cause
actual results to differ materially from those suggested by the forward-looking statements;
accordingly, there can be no assurance that such indicated results will be realized. These factors
include:


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the impact of recent and future federal and state regulatory change, including legislative and regulatory initiatives
regarding deregulation and restructuring of the electric utility industry, and also changes in environmental, tax, and
other laws and regulations to which Southern Company and its subsidiaries are subject, as well as changes in
application of existing laws and regulations;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>current and future litigation, regulatory investigations, proceedings, or inquiries, including the pending EPA civil
actions against certain Southern Company subsidiaries, IRS audits, and Mirant related matters;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the effects, extent, and timing of the entry of additional competition in the markets in which Southern Company&#146;s
subsidiaries operate;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>variations in demand for electricity and gas, including those relating to weather, the general economy and population,
and business growth (and declines);</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>available sources and costs of fuels;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>ability to control costs;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>investment performance of Southern Company&#146;s employee benefit plans;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>advances in technology;</TD>
</TR>

    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>

develop new opportunities;</TD>

    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the ability to obtain new short- and long-term contracts with neighboring utilities;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the direct or indirect effect on Southern Company&#146;s business resulting from terrorist incidents and the threat of
terrorist incidents;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>interest rate fluctuations and financial market conditions and the results of financing efforts, including Southern
Company&#146;s and its subsidiaries&#146; credit ratings;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the ability of Southern Company and its subsidiaries to obtain additional generating capacity at competitive prices;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>catastrophic events such as fires, earthquakes, explosions, floods, hurricanes, or other similar occurrences;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the direct or indirect effects on Southern Company&#146;s business resulting from incidents similar to the August&nbsp;2003 power
outage in the Northeast;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the effect of accounting pronouncements issued periodically by standard setting bodies; and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" nowrap align="left">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>other factors discussed elsewhere herein and in other reports filed by the registrants from time to time with the SEC.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>The registrants expressly disclaim any obligation to update any forward-looking statements.</B>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">6
</DIV>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">0.350</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">The accompanying notes as
they relate to Southern Company are an integral part
of these condensed financial statements.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">8

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>


<DIV align="left">
<A name="104"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</B></DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B></DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FIRST QUARTER 2005 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2004


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Discussion of the results of operations is focused on Southern Company&#146;s primary business of
electricity sales in the Southeast by the retail operating companies &#150; Alabama Power, Georgia
Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, and Savannah Electric &#150; and Southern Power. Southern Power
is an electric wholesale generation subsidiary with market-based rate authority. Southern
Company&#146;s other business activities include investments in synthetic fuels and leveraged lease
projects, telecommunications, energy-related services, and natural gas marketing. For additional
information on these businesses, see BUSINESS &#150; The SOUTHERN System &#150; &#147;Retail Operating Companies,&#148;
&#147;Southern Power,&#148; and &#147;Other Business&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 of the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company continues to focus on several key performance indicators. These indicators
include customer satisfaction, peak season equivalent forced outage rate, return on equity, and
earnings per share. For additional information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW &#150; &#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company&#146;s first quarter 2005 earnings were $323&nbsp;million ($0.43 per share) compared
with $331&nbsp;million ($0.45 per share) in the first quarter 2004. Earnings in the first quarter 2005
decreased due to milder than normal weather, the expiration of certain provisions of Georgia
Power&#146;s three-year retail rate plan ending December&nbsp;31, 2004 (2001 Retail Rate Plan), and higher
non-fuel operation and maintenance costs as compared to the first quarter of 2004. These decreases
were partially offset by a base rate increase at Georgia Power and customer growth in the Southern
Company service area.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the following:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail revenues. </I>The chart below reflects the primary drivers of the 5.8% increase in retail
revenues in the first quarter 2005 compared to the prior year. Changes in revenue related to cost
recovery mechanisms such as fuel and environmental have no effect on net income. In the first
quarter 2005, retail kilowatt-hour energy sales decreased by 0.8% from the same period a year ago,
primarily due to milder weather. The decrease was partially offset by continued customer and demand
growth due to sustained economic growth in the Southeast. The number of retail customers increased
by 1.6% and weather-adjusted average consumption by retail customers increased by 1.1% in the first
quarter 2005 when compared with the first quarter 2004.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">13
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other electric revenues. </I>In the first quarter 2005, when compared to the same period in 2004,
other electric revenues increased $7.5&nbsp;million, or 8.0%, primarily due to higher transmission and
outdoor lighting revenues of $2.4&nbsp;million and $1.5&nbsp;million, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense</I>. During the first quarter 2005, fuel expense was higher due to a 10.7% increase
in the average unit cost of fuel per net kilowatt-hour generated when compared to the same period
in the prior year. Increases in fuel expense at the retail operating companies are generally
offset by fuel revenues and do not affect net income.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power expense. </I>The decrease in the first quarter 2005 for purchased power compared
with the same period last year is primarily a result of lower kilowatt-hour purchases and a
decrease in the cost of purchased power per kilowatt-hour. These expenses do not have a
significant impact on earnings since energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operations and maintenance expense. </I>The $68.7&nbsp;million increase in other operations and
maintenance in the first quarter 2005 is mainly attributable to $45&nbsp;million of expenses recorded by
Alabama Power in accordance with an accounting order approved by the Alabama PSC to offset the
costs of Hurricane Ivan and restore the natural disaster reserve. In accordance with the
accounting order, Alabama Power also returned certain regulatory liabilities related to deferred
taxes to its retail customers; therefore, the combined effects of this accounting order had no
impact on net income. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Gulf Power
and Alabama Power Storm Damage Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K and &#147;Income taxes&#148; below for additional information. In
addition, fossil and hydro expenses increased $13.3&nbsp;million as compared to the prior year primarily
due to lower than normal operation and maintenance spending in the first quarter 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization expense</I>. The $52&nbsp;million increase in depreciation and
amortization in the first quarter of 2005 is due to the expiration in 2004 of certain provisions in
Georgia Power&#146;s 2001 Retail Rate Plan. In accordance with the 2001 Retail Rate Plan, Georgia Power
amortized an accelerated cost recovery liability equally as a credit to amortization expense and
recognized new Georgia PSC-certified purchased power costs in rates evenly over the three years
ended December&nbsp;31, 2004. This treatment resulted in a credit to amortization expense of $47
million during the first quarter of 2004. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern
Company under &#147;Georgia Power Retail Rate Activity&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional
information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Allowance for equity funds used during construction</I>. The first quarter 2005 increase in AFUDC
compared to the same period in the prior year relates primarily to construction of the McIntosh
combined cycle units 10 and 11 by Georgia Power and Savannah Electric. See Note 3 to the financial
statements of Southern Company under &#147;Plant McIntosh Construction Project&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for further information.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">14
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES<BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized. </I>The increase in interest expense, net of
amounts capitalized in the first quarter 2005 when compared to the same period in 2004 is mainly
attributed to an increase in the amount of senior notes outstanding and lower amounts of interest
capitalized as projects have reached completion, partially offset by refinancing long-term debt
with lower interest-rate debt. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Financing Activities&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and herein for
additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Income taxes. </I>The decrease in income taxes in the first quarter 2005 compared to the prior
year is primarily due to the impact of the Alabama PSC accounting order discussed under &#147;Other
operations and maintenance expense&#148; above and is expected to
maintain Southern Company&#146;s annual effective income tax rate at
approximately 27% for 2005. See Note 5 to the financial statements of
Southern Company in Item 8 of the Form 10-K and Note (N) to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of future earnings
potential. The level of Southern Company&#146;s future earnings depends on numerous factors that affect
the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Southern Company&#146;s primary business of selling
electricity. These factors include the retail operating companies&#146; ability to maintain a stable
regulatory environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to recover costs
related to growing demand and increasingly stringent environmental standards. Another major factor
is the profitability of the competitive market-based wholesale generating business and federal
regulatory policy, which may impact Southern Company&#146;s level of participation in this
market. Future earnings for the electricity business in the near term will depend, in part, upon
growth in energy sales, which is subject to a number of factors. These factors include weather,
competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities, energy conservation practiced by
customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and the rate of economic
growth in the service area. For additional information relating to these issues, see BUSINESS &#150;
The SOUTHERN System &#150; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE
EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For additional information, including information on
certain environmental litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS
POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Southern Company under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;11, 2005, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit accepted Georgia Power&#146;s
petition for review of the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia&#146;s December&nbsp;15,
2004 order related to the Plant Wansley environmental litigation. Oral argument on that appeal has
not been scheduled. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under
&#147;Environmental Matters &#150; Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Environmental Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The EPA issued the final Clean Air Interstate Rule on March&nbsp;10, 2005. The rule addresses sulfur
dioxide (SO<SUB>2</SUB>) and nitrogen oxide (NO<SUB>x</SUB>) emissions that contribute to
nonattainment of the eight-hour ozone and fine particulate matter National Ambient Air Quality
Standards. Twenty-eight eastern states, including each of the



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">15
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES<BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">states within Southern Company&#146;s
service area, are subject to the fine particulate and/or the
eight-hour ozone requirements set forth within the rule. The rule may require
additional reductions of NO<SUB>x</SUB> and/or SO<SUB>2</SUB> to be achieved by the installation of additional controls at Southern Company facilities or through the
purchase of allowances. The impact of this final rule on Southern Company will, however, depend on
the development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be
determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced the final Clean Air Mercury Rule, selecting a
cap-and-trade approach to be implemented in two phases, 2010 and 2018. The rule sets a permanent
cap on emissions at the 2018 level and provides for an emissions allowance trading market. The
impact of this final rule on Southern Company will depend on resolution of legal challenges and the
development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be determined
at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced plans to extend the deadline for issuance of final rules
addressing Best Available Retrofit Technology standards under its Regional Haze program until June
15, 2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The EPA published a proposed rule on April&nbsp;20, 2005 to approve redesignation of the Atlanta
metro area to &#147;attainment&#148; under the one-hour ozone standard.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FERC and State PSC Matters</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and State
PSC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for
measuring generation market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to
assess Southern Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory. Each of the
retail operating companies and Southern Power has authorization from the FERC to sell power to
non-affiliates at market-based prices. The retail operating companies and Southern Power also
have FERC authority to make short-term opportunity sales at market rates. Specific FERC
approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based contract with an affiliate. As
directed by this order, on February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company submitted additional information
related to generation dominance in its retail service territory. Any new market-based rate
transactions in its retail service territory entered into after February&nbsp;27, 2005 will be
subject to refund to the level of the default cost-based rates, pending the outcome of the
proceeding. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures are ultimately applied,
the retail operating companies and Southern Power may be required to charge cost-based rates for
certain wholesale sales in the Southern Company retail service territory, which may be lower
than negotiated market-based rates. The impact of such sales through
March 31, 2005 is not material to Southern Company&#146;s net income. The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in
which the final methodology for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be
ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Generation Interconnection Agreements</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and State PSC Matters
&#150; Generation Interconnection Agreements&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for
information on the FERC&#146;s Order 2003 related to standardization of generation interconnection
agreements and procedures. The FERC has indicated that Order 2003, which was effective January&nbsp;20,
2004, is to be applied prospectively to interconnection agreements. Subsidiaries of Tenaska, Inc.,
as counterparties to three previously executed interconnection agreements with subsidiaries of
Southern Company, have filed complaints at the FERC requesting that the FERC modify the agreements
and that Southern Company refund a total of $19&nbsp;million previously paid for interconnection
facilities, with interest. Southern Company has also received similar requests from other entities
totaling approximately $14&nbsp;million. Southern Company has

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Retail Fuel Cost Recovery</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The retail operating companies each have established fuel cost recovery rates approved by their
respective state PSCs. In recent quarters, the retail operating companies have experienced higher
than expected fuel costs for coal and gas. These higher fuel costs have increased the under
recovered fuel costs included in the balance sheets. The retail operating companies will continue
to monitor the under recovered fuel cost balance in light of these higher fuel costs.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power fuel costs are recovered under Rate ECR (Energy Cost Recovery), which provides
for the addition of a fuel and energy cost factor to base rates. Alabama Power&#146;s under recovered
fuel costs as of March&nbsp;31, 2005 totaled $96.4&nbsp;million as compared to $101.6&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31,
2004. Alabama Power increased its fuel billing factor in April&nbsp;2005. See Note 3 to the financial
statements of Southern Company under &#147;Alabama Power Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K and Note (H)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On February&nbsp;18, 2005, Georgia Power filed a request with the Georgia PSC for a fuel cost
recovery rate increase. The requested increase, representing an average annual increase in
revenues of approximately 11.8%, will allow for the recovery of fuel costs based on an estimate of
future fuel costs, as well as the collection of the existing under recovery of fuel costs. The
Georgia PSC may require that this existing under recovery be collected over a period greater than
twelve months. Georgia Power&#146;s under recovered fuel costs as of March&nbsp;31, 2005 totaled $455.2
million. Hearings before the Georgia PSC were held in April&nbsp;2005. A final decision from the
Georgia PSC is expected in May&nbsp;2005 with the new fuel rate effective June 1. The final outcome of
the filing cannot be determined at this time. For additional information on Georgia Power&#146;s current
fuel cost recovery rate, see Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Georgia
Power Retail Rate Activity&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (I)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Storm Damage Cost Recovery</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and State PSC
Matters &#151; Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 3 to the
financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Storm Damage Reserves&#148; and &#147;Gulf Power and
Alabama Power Storm Damage Recovery,&#148; respectively, in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. Each retail
operating company maintains a reserve for property damage to cover the cost of damages from
major storms to its transmission and distribution lines and the cost of uninsured damages to its
generation facilities and other property.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Hurricane Ivan hit Gulf Power&#146;s service territory in September&nbsp;2004. In March&nbsp;2005, the
Florida PSC approved a Stipulation and Settlement between Gulf Power, the Office of Public
Counsel for the State of Florida, and the Florida Industrial Power Users Group which allows Gulf
Power to recover the retail portion of $51.7&nbsp;million, the projected reserve deficiency, plus
interest and revenue taxes, from customers over a 24-month period beginning in April&nbsp;2005. In
connection with the Stipulation, Gulf Power has agreed that it will not seek any additional
increase in its base rates and charges to become effective on or before March&nbsp;1, 2007.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Mirant Related Matters</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Other Matters&#148; of Southern
Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Mirant Related
Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein under
&#147;Mirant Related Matters.&#148; In July&nbsp;2003, Mirant filed for voluntary reorganization under Chapter

Company that it was investigating, on behalf of a committee of independent Mirant directors,
potential claims against Southern Company. On March&nbsp;25, 2005, Mirant filed with the U.S.
Bankruptcy Court for the Northern District of Texas a First Amended Disclosure Statement relating to Mirant&#146;s plan of reorganization. In the First
Amended Disclosure Statement, Mirant disclosed that its board of directors has authorized
litigation against Southern Company to recover certain transfers made by Mirant to Southern Company
from 1999 through 2001. Other than identifying these transfers, the First Amended Disclosure
Statement provided no factual or legal basis for any claim against Southern Company. Southern
Company believes there is no meritorious basis for a claim and intends to vigorously defend itself
in the event that Mirant brings an action to recover any amounts in connection with these
transfers. The ultimate outcome of any potential action by Mirant cannot be determined at this
time. Southern Company has various other contingent liabilities associated with Mirant, including
guarantees of contractual commitments, litigation, and joint and several liabilities in connection
with the consolidated federal income tax return. The ultimate outcome of such contingent
liabilities cannot now be determined.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Income Tax Matters</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Leveraged Lease Transactions</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Income Tax Matters -
Leveraged Lease Transactions&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements
of Southern Company under &#147;Income Tax Matters &#151; Leveraged Lease Transactions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K and Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for information regarding IRS
challenges to Southern Company&#146;s transactions related to international leveraged leases that could
have material impacts on Southern Company&#146;s financial statements. The ultimate outcome of these
matters cannot now be determined.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Synthetic Fuel Tax Credits</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">As discussed in Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Income Tax Matters -
Synthetic Fuel Tax Credits&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K, Southern Company has investments in two
entities that produce synthetic fuel and receive tax credits under Section&nbsp;29 of the IRC. In
accordance with Section&nbsp;29 of the IRC, these tax credits are subject to limitation as the annual
average price of oil (as determined by the DOE) increases over a specified, inflation-adjusted
dollar amount published in the spring of the subsequent year. Southern Company, along with its
partners in these investments, will continue to monitor oil prices. Any indicated potential
limitation on these credits could affect either the timing or the amount of the credit recognition
and could also require an impairment analysis of these investments by Southern Company. Subsequent
to March&nbsp;31, 2005, Southern Company entered into a derivative transaction designed to reduce its
exposure to the potential phase-out of these credits in 2005. The purchased
option, which had an initial fair value of approximately $7 million,
will be marked to market over the remainder of the year through other
income (expense), net.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Other Matters</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On April&nbsp;8, 2005, Southern Power entered into an agreement with Constellation Power, Inc. and
certain other subsidiaries of Constellation Energy Group, Inc. to acquire all of the outstanding
general and limited partnership interests of Oleander Power Project, L.P. (Oleander), for an
aggregate purchase price of approximately $206&nbsp;million. The purchase price is subject to certain
working capital and timing of closing adjustments. Oleander owns a dual-fueled generating plant in
Brevard County, Florida with a nominal installed capacity of 680 MW. The entire output of the
plant is sold under separate PPAs with Florida Power &#038; Light Company and Seminole Electric
Cooperative, Inc. The PPAs expire in 2007 and 2009, respectively. The acquisition is subject to
certain regulatory approvals, including the approval of the FERC, as well as review by the Federal
Trade Commission under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act.

</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course
of business. In addition, Southern Company&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive
governmental regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over
environmental issues and claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, and
citizen enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout the United
States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous
materials have become more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such litigation against Southern
Company and its subsidiaries cannot be predicted at this time; however, management does not
anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from such current proceedings would have a
material adverse effect on Southern Company&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various
contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings potential.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company prepares its consolidated financial statements in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are
described in Note 1 to the financial statements of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K.
In the application of these policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact
on Southern Company&#146;s results of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and
measurements could produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in the
financial statements. Also see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; ACCOUNTING POLICIES -
&#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the
Form 10-K for a complete discussion of Southern Company&#146;s critical accounting policies and
estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation, Contingent Obligations, and Unbilled Revenues.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123R, Share-Based Payments, was issued in December&nbsp;2004. This statement
requires that compensation cost relating to share-based payment transactions be recognized in
financial statements. That cost will be measured based on the grant date fair value of the
equity or liability instruments issued. In April&nbsp;2005, the SEC amended the compliance dates for
FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123R. For Southern Company, this statement is now effective beginning
January&nbsp;1, 2006. Although the compensation expense calculation required under the revised
statement differs slightly, the impacts on Southern Company&#146;s financial statements are expected
to be similar to the pro forma disclosures included in Note 1 to the financial statements of
Southern Company under &#147;Stock Options&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and in Note (C)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;47 (FIN 47), Accounting for Conditional Asset Retirement Obligations,
was issued in March&nbsp;2005. This interpretation requires that asset retirement obligations be
recorded when a legal obligation exists even though the timing and/or the method of settlement are
conditional on a future event. For Southern Company, FIN 47 is effective no later than December
31, 2005. Southern Company is currently assessing the impact of FIN 47 on its balance sheet;
however, adoption is not currently expected to have a material impact on Southern Company&#146;s income
statement.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued Staff Position No.&nbsp;109-1 (FSP 109-1), Application of FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;109, Accounting for Income Taxes, to the Tax Deduction on Qualified Production
Activities provided by the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004, which requires that the generation
deduction for utilities be accounted for as a special tax deduction rather than as a tax rate
reduction. Southern Company adopted FSP 109-1 in the first quarter of 2005 with no material impact
on its financial statements.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">19
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES<BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company&#146;s financial condition continued to be strong at March&nbsp;31, 2005. Net cash flow
from operating activities totaled $170&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2005, compared to $307
million for the first quarter 2004. The $137&nbsp;million decrease in 2005 resulted primarily from
higher fuel costs at the retail operating companies. Those costs are recoverable in future
periods and are reflected on the balance sheets as under recovered regulatory clause revenues.
Gross property additions to utility plant were $480&nbsp;million in the first quarter 2005. The
majority of funds needed for gross property additions since 2000 has been provided from
operating activities.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant balance sheet changes include a $237&nbsp;million increase in long-term debt for the
first quarter 2005 due to the replacement of short-term financing with long-term debt, consistent
with Southern Company&#146;s finance policy, and an increase of $178&nbsp;million in property, plant, and
equipment.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The market price of Southern Company&#146;s common stock at March&nbsp;31, 2005 was $31.83 per share and
the book value was $13.98 per share, representing a market-to-book ratio of 228%, compared to
$33.52, $13.86, and 242%, respectively, at the end of 2004. The dividend for the first quarter
2005 was $0.3575 per share compared to $0.35 per share in the first quarter 2004. In April&nbsp;2005,
the dividend was increased to $0.3725 per share for the dividend payable in June&nbsp;2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The retail operating companies, Southern Power, and SCS have each maintained investment grade
ratings from the major rating agencies.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150;&#147;Capital Requirements
and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a description of
Southern Company&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program and other funding requirements
associated with scheduled maturities of long-term debt, as well as the related interest, preferred
stock dividends, leases, trust funding requirements, and other purchase commitments. Approximately
$745&nbsp;million will be required by March&nbsp;31, 2006 for redemptions and maturities of long-term debt.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company intends to meet its future capital needs through internal cash flow and external
security issuances. The amounts and timing of additional equity capital to be raised will be
contingent on Southern Company&#146;s investment opportunities. The retail operating companies and
Southern Power plan to obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources similar to those used in the past,
which were primarily from operating cash flows, security issuances, and term loan and short-term
borrowings. However, the a mount, type, and timing of any financings, if needed, will
depend upon market conditions and regulatory approval. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form
10-K for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To meet short term cash needs and contingencies, the Southern Company system had at March&nbsp;31,
2005 approximately $382&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and approximately $3.2&nbsp;billion of
unused credit arrangements with banks, of which $1.8&nbsp;billion expire in 2005 and $1.4&nbsp;billion expire
in 2006 and beyond. Of the facilities maturing in 2005 and 2006, $1.2&nbsp;billion contain provisions
allowing two-year term loans executable at the expiration date and $275&nbsp;million contain provisions
allowing one-year term loans executable at the expiration date. These unused credit arrangements
also provide liquidity support to variable rate pollution control bonds and commercial paper
programs. Southern Company expects to renew its credit



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">20
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES<BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">facilities, as needed, prior to expiration. The retail operating companies may also meet
short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial
paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of each of the retail
operating companies. At March&nbsp;31, 2005, the Southern Company system had outstanding commercial
paper of $714.5&nbsp;million and extendible commercial notes of $24.6&nbsp;million. Management believes that
the need for working capital can be adequately met by utilizing commercial paper programs and lines
of credit without maintaining large cash balances.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Off-Balance Sheet
Financing Arrangements&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 7 to the financial statements of
Southern Company under &#147;Operating Leases&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information related to
Mississippi Power&#146;s lease of a combined cycle generating facility at Plant Daniel.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in
payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain
contracts that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit
rating change to BBB- or Baa3 or below. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity
purchases and sales. At March&nbsp;31, 2005, the maximum potential collateral requirements at a BBB-
or Baa3 rating were approximately $43&nbsp;million. The maximum potential collateral requirements at
a rating below BBB- or Baa3 were approximately $326&nbsp;million. Generally, collateral may be
provided for by a Southern Company guaranty, letter of credit, or cash. Southern Company is
also party to certain derivative agreements that could require collateral and/or accelerated
payment in the event of a credit rating change to below investment grade. These agreements are
primarily for natural gas price and interest rate risk management activities. At March&nbsp;31, 2005,
Southern Company and its subsidiaries had no exposure under these contracts.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed
materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2004 reporting period. In addition, Southern Company is
not aware of any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near
term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, the retail operating companies have limited exposure to
market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. In
addition, Southern Power&#146;s exposure to market volatility in commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity is limited because its long-term sales contracts shift substantially all fuel cost
responsibility to the purchaser. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in
electricity prices, the retail operating companies and Southern Power enter into fixed-price
contracts for the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market and,
to a lesser extent, into similar contracts for gas purchases. The retail operating companies
have implemented fuel hedging programs at the instruction of their respective state PSCs.
Southern Company GAS also has in place a risk management program to substantially mitigate its
exposure to price volatility for its natural gas purchases.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">21
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements of Southern Company under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note
(F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In the first three months of 2005, Southern Company and its subsidiaries issued $500&nbsp;million of
senior notes and $55&nbsp;million of common stock through employee and director stock plans. The
proceeds were primarily used to refund senior notes and other long-term debt and to fund ongoing
construction projects. The remainder was used to repay short-term indebtedness. See Southern
Company&#146;s Condensed Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows herein for further details on financing
activities during the first three months of 2005.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent to March&nbsp;31, 2005, Georgia Power issued $125&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;Y 5.80% Senior
Notes. Additionally, Georgia Power refinanced $85&nbsp;million of obligations incurred in connection
with pollution control bonds. Also, subsequent to March&nbsp;31, 2005, Georgia Power entered
into an interest rate swap related to the Series&nbsp;Y 5.80% Senior Notes issued in April&nbsp;2005. The
interest rate swap had a fixed rate of 4.984%, a final maturity of 2015, and was terminated at a
cost of $0.3&nbsp;million. This cost will be amortized over a 10-year period.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements and
contractual obligations, Southern Company and its subsidiaries plan to continue, when economically
feasible, a program to retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost
capital if market conditions permit.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148;
herein for each registrant and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of each registrant under

<DIV align="left">
<A name="113"></A>
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Item&nbsp;4. Controls and Procedures.</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;Evaluation of disclosure controls and procedures.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Southern Company, Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, and Southern
Power </U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of the end of the period covered by this quarterly report, Southern Company, Alabama Power,
Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, and Southern Power conducted separate evaluations
under the supervision and with the participation of each company&#146;s management, including the Chief
Executive Officer and the Chief Financial Officer, of the effectiveness of the design and operation
of the disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Sections&nbsp;13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) of the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934). Based upon these evaluations, the Chief Executive Officer and
the Chief Financial Officer, in each case, concluded that the disclosure controls and procedures
are effective in alerting them in a timely manner to material information relating to their company
(including its consolidated subsidiaries, if any) required to be included in periodic filings with
the SEC.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Savannah Electric</U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of the end of the period covered by this quarterly report, Savannah Electric conducted an
evaluation under the supervision and with the participation of its management, including the Chief
Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, of the effectiveness of the design and operation of
the disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Section&nbsp;13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) of the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934). Based upon these evaluations, which took into consideration the
revisions made in February&nbsp;2005 to Savannah Electric&#146;s process and controls related to unbilled
revenues which are described below, the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief Financial Officer
concluded that the disclosure controls and procedures were effective in alerting them in a timely
manner to material information relating to Savannah Electric required to be included in periodic
filings with the SEC.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As disclosed in the Form 10-K, in connection with the review and preparation of the financial
statements of Savannah Electric for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, errors in Savannah Electric&#146;s
estimates of unbilled revenues for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002 and periods prior to
2002 were identified. The errors also affected Savannah Electric&#146;s previously issued financial
statements for the quarters ended March&nbsp;31, June&nbsp;30, and September&nbsp;30, 2004 and 2003. Savannah
Electric&#146;s financial statements were restated to reflect adjustments to the financial information
previously reported. See Note 9 to the financial statements of Savannah Electric in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February&nbsp;2005, management revised its process and controls related to estimating unbilled
revenues to utilize a gross change methodology that reverses each period&#146;s estimate in total in the
following period.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">23
</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;Changes in internal controls.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Southern Company, Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, and Southern
Power </U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There have been no changes in Southern Company&#146;s, Alabama Power&#146;s, Georgia Power&#146;s, Gulf
Power&#146;s, Mississippi Power&#146;s, or Southern Power&#146;s internal control over financial reporting (as
such term is defined in Rules&nbsp;13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934)
during the first quarter of 2005 that have materially affected or are reasonably likely to
materially affect Southern Company&#146;s, Alabama Power&#146;s, Georgia Power&#146;s, Gulf Power&#146;s, Mississippi
Power&#146;s, or Southern Power&#146;s internal control over financial reporting.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Savannah Electric</U>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As described above under &#147;Disclosure Controls and Procedures,&#148; Savannah Electric made changes
to its process and controls related to estimating unbilled revenues in February&nbsp;2005. Otherwise,
there have been no changes in Savannah Electric&#146;s internal control over financial reporting (as
such term is defined in Rules&nbsp;13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934)
during the first quarter of 2005 that have materially affected or are reasonably likely to
materially affect Savannah Electric&#146;s internal control over financial reporting.

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">25

<P><HR noshade><P>

<DIV align="left">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>CONDENSED STATEMENTS OF INCOME (UNAUDITED)</B>


<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->

    <TD width="80%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
CONDENSED BALANCE SHEETS (UNAUDITED)


<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="80%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">The accompanying notes as they relate to Alabama Power are an integral part of these condensed financial statements.




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">29
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B>


<DIV align="left">
<A name="105"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FIRST QUARTER 2005 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2004


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Discussion of the results of operations is focused on Alabama Power&#146;s business of
electricity sales to retail customers within its traditional service area located within the State
of Alabama and to wholesale customers in the Southeast. Many factors affect the opportunities,
challenges, and risks of Alabama Power&#146;s business of selling electricity. These factors
include the ability to maintain a stable regulatory environment, to achieve energy sales growth
while containing costs, and to recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stringent
environmental standards.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power continues to focus on several key performance indicators. These indicators
include customer satisfaction, peak season equivalent forced outage rate, and return on equity. For
additional information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW &#150;
&#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the first quarter 2005 was $93.4
million compared to $90.7&nbsp;million for the corresponding period of 2004. Earnings in the first
quarter of 2005 increased by $2.7&nbsp;million, or 2.9%, primarily due to an increase in industrial
revenues reflecting sustained economic strength and a decrease in interest expense. In addition,
retail rates increased 1% in January&nbsp;2005 resulting from an environmental rate order of the Alabama
PSC.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the following:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail revenues</I>. The chart below reflects the primary drivers of the 4.8% decrease in retail
revenues in the first quarter 2005 compared to the same period in the prior year. Energy cost
recovery revenues and revenues associated with the recovery of costs associated with the PPAs
certificated by the Alabama PSC (Rate CNP-PPA) generally do not affect net income. Excluding these
revenues, retail revenues decreased by $1.2&nbsp;million, or 0.2%, for the first quarter 2005 when
compared to the corresponding period in 2004. Kilowatt-hour energy sales to residential and
commercial customers decreased 3.7% and 1.6%, respectively, for the first quarter 2005 when
compared to the corresponding period of 2004 primarily due to less favorable weather conditions in
2005. Kilowatt-hour energy sales to industrial customers increased 3.2% for the first quarter 2005
when compared to the corresponding period of 2004 primarily due to improved sales mainly in the
pulp and paper, mining, and automotive sectors.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">30
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale </I>&#150; <I>affiliates and Purchased power expense </I>&#150; <I>affiliates</I>. Energy sales to and
purchases from affiliated companies within the Southern Company electric system vary from period to
period depending on demand and the availability and cost of generating resources at each company.
These sales and purchases are made in accordance with the affiliated company interchange agreement,
as approved by the FERC. Sales for resale to affiliates increased in the first quarter 2005 when
compared to the corresponding period in 2004 primarily due to a 21% increase in kilowatt-hour sales
to affiliates from Alabama Power&#146;s more economical available capacity and price increases related
to the recovery of increased fuel-related expenses. Purchased power from affiliates decreased in
the first quarter 2005 compared to the same period in 2004 due to a
20.1% reduction in energy
purchased due to increased self-generation, which was more economical. Excluding the increase in
capacity revenues of $1.3&nbsp;million received under the interchange agreement, these transactions did
not have a significant impact on earnings since the related energy is sold at marginal cost, and
energy purchases are generally offset by energy revenues through Alabama Power&#146;s energy cost
recovery clause.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power expense &#150; non-affiliates</I>. Purchased power from non-affiliates will vary
depending on the market cost of available energy compared to the cost of Alabama Power and Southern
Company system owned generation, demand for energy within the Southern Company service territory,
and availability of Southern Company system generation. In the first quarter 2005, purchased power
from non-affiliates decreased when compared to the same period in 2004 primarily due to a 13.3%
decrease in the amount of energy purchased due to increased self-generation and a 22.1% decrease in
the average price of non-affiliate purchased power. These transactions did not have a significant
impact on earnings since energy purchases are generally offset by energy revenues through Alabama
Power&#146;s energy cost recovery clause.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>Fuel expense was higher in the first quarter 2005 when compared to the
corresponding period in 2004 mainly due to a 13.9% increase in coal prices and a 14.3% increase in
generation from coal-fired generating facilities. The increase in generation from coal-fired
facilities in the first quarter 2005 when compared to the first quarter 2004 is mainly due to a
42.6% decrease in generation from Alabama Power&#146;s gas-fired generating facilities because of
increased gas prices. Since energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues, these
expenses do not have a significant impact on earnings.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Maintenance expense. </I>The increase in maintenance expense for the first quarter 2005 when
compared to the same period in 2004 is attributed to a $10.8&nbsp;million increase to transmission
expense and a $34.2&nbsp;million increase in distribution expense. This increase is due to the Alabama
PSC accounting order to offset the costs of the damage from Hurricane Ivan in September&nbsp;2004 and to
restore a balance in the natural disaster reserve. See Notes 1 and 3 to the financial statements
of Alabama Power under &#147;Natural Disaster Reserve&#148; and &#147;Natural Disaster Cost Recovery,&#148;
respectively, in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information. Also, see &#147;Income tax
expense&#148; below for additional offsetting impacts of the Alabama PSC&#146;s order.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">31
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
