<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Income
tax expense.</I> In accordance with the Alabama PSC accounting order
described above, Alabama Power returned $27.7 million of regulatory
liabilities related to deferred income taxes to its retail customers.
The remainder of the decrease in income tax expense in the first
quarter 2005 primarily reflects the $17.3 million tax effect of the
additional maintenance expenses recorded under the accounting order.
For additional information, see &#147;Maintenance expense&#148; above
and Note 3 to the financial statements of Alabama Power under
&#147;Natural Disaster Cost Recovery&#148; in Item 8 of the Form
10-K. The impact of this accounting order is expected to reduce
Alabama Power&#146;s annual effective income tax rate to
approximately 34% for 2005. See Note 5 to the financial statements of
Alabama Power in Item 8 of the Form 10-K and Note (N) to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized. </I>The decrease in interest expense, net of
amounts capitalized during the first quarter 2005 when compared to the same period in 2004 is the
result of refinancing higher cost debt. For additional information, see FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Financing Activities&#148; herein and in Item&nbsp;7 of Alabama Power of the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Alabama Power&#146;s future
earnings potential. The level of Alabama Power&#146;s future earnings depends on numerous factors that
affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Alabama Power&#146;s business of selling
electricity. These factors include Alabama Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to recover costs related to
growing demand and increasingly stringent environmental standards. Future earnings in the near
term will depend, in part, upon growth in energy sales, which is subject to a number of factors.
These factors include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities, energy
conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and
the rate of economic growth in Alabama Power&#146;s service area. For additional information relating
to these issues, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Alabama
Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For additional information, including information on
certain environmental litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS
POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The EPA issued the final Clean Air Interstate Rule on March&nbsp;10, 2005. The rule addresses
sulfur dioxide (SO<SUB>2</SUB>) and nitrogen oxide (NO<SUB>x</SUB>) emissions that contribute to
nonattainment of the eight-hour ozone and fine particulate matter National Ambient Air Quality
Standards. Twenty-eight eastern states, including the State of Alabama, are subject to the fine
particulate and/or the eight-hour ozone requirements set forth within the rule. The rule may
require additional reductions of NO<SUB>x</SUB> and/or SO<SUB>2</SUB> to be achieved by the
installation of additional controls at Alabama Power&#146;s facilities or through the purchase of
allowances. The impact of this final rule on Alabama Power will, however, depend on the development
and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced the final Clean Air Mercury Rule, selecting a
cap-and-trade approach to be implemented in two phases, 2010 and 2018. The rule sets a permanent
cap on emissions at the 2018 level and provides for an emissions allowance trading market. The impact of this final rule
on Alabama Power will depend on resolution of legal challenges and the development and
implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">32
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced plans to extend the deadline for issuance of final rules
addressing Best Available Retrofit Technology standards under its Regional Haze program until June
15, 2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FERC and Alabama PSC Matters</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and
Alabama PSC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for
measuring generation market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to
assess Southern Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory. Alabama
Power has authorization from the FERC to sell power to non-affiliates at market-based prices.
Alabama Power, through SCS as agent, also has FERC authority to make short-term opportunity
sales at market rates. Specific FERC approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based
contract with an affiliate. As directed by this order, on February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company
submitted additional information related to generation dominance in its retail service
territory. Any new market-based rate transactions in Southern Company&#146;s retail service
territory entered into after February&nbsp;27, 2005 will be subject to refund to the level of the
default cost-based rates, pending the outcome of the proceeding. In the event that the FERC&#146;s
default mitigation measures are ultimately applied Alabama Power may be required to charge
cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales in the Southern Company retail service territory,
which may be lower than negotiated market-based rates. The impact of
such sales through March 31, 2005 is not material to Alabama
Power&#146;s net income. The final outcome of this matter will
depend on the form in which the final methodology for assessing generation market power and
mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Generation Interconnection Agreements</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and Alabama PSC
Matters &#150; Generation Interconnection Agreements&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for
information on the FERC&#146;s Order 2003 related to standardization of generation interconnection
agreements and procedures. The FERC has indicated that Order 2003, which was effective January&nbsp;20,
2004, is to be applied prospectively to interconnection agreements. Subsidiaries of Tenaska, Inc.,
as counterparties to two previously executed interconnection agreements with Alabama Power, have
filed complaints at the FERC requesting that the FERC modify the agreements and that Alabama Power
refund a total of $11&nbsp;million previously paid for interconnection facilities, with interest.
Alabama Power has also received similar requests from other entities totaling $7&nbsp;million. Alabama
Power has opposed such relief, and the proceedings are still pending. The impact of Order 2003 and
its subsequent rehearings on Alabama Power and the final results of these matters cannot be
determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Rate Filing</I>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On October&nbsp;5, 2004, the Alabama PSC approved a specific rate mechanism for the recovery of
Alabama Power&#146;s retail costs associated with environmental laws, regulations, or other such
mandates. The rate mechanism began operation in January&nbsp;2005 and provides for the recovery of
these costs pursuant to a factor that will be calculated annually. Environmental costs to be
recovered include operation and maintenance expenses, depreciation, and a return on invested
capital. Retail rates have increased 1&nbsp;percent in 2005, which should yield an annual recovery
of approximately $33&nbsp;million, and are expected to increase an additional 1&nbsp;percent in 2006. In
conjunction with the Alabama PSC&#146;s approval, Alabama Power
agreed to a moratorium until March&nbsp;2007 on any retail rate increase under the previously approved Rate Stabilization
and Equalization plan (RSE). Any increase in March&nbsp;2007 would be based upon the earned return
on retail common equity at December&nbsp;31, 2006. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Alabama
Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for further information on
the RSE plan.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">33
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Retail Fuel Cost Recovery</I>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power has established fuel cost recovery rates approved by the Alabama PSC. Alabama
Power&#146;s under recovered fuel costs as of March&nbsp;31, 2005 totaled $96.4&nbsp;million as compared to $101.6
million at December&nbsp;31, 2004. Alabama Power increased its fuel billing factor in April&nbsp;2005.
Alabama Power will continue to monitor the under recovered fuel cost balance to determine if an
additional adjustment to billing rates should be requested from the Alabama PSC. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#150; &#147;Revenues&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3
to the financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K and Note (H)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Other Matters</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of
business. In addition, Alabama Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive governmental
regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and
claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, and citizen enforcement of
environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout the United States. In particular,
personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become
more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such litigation against Alabama Power cannot be predicted
at this time; however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from
such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on Alabama Power&#146;s financial
statements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various
contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings potential.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Alabama Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could produce estimates
that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS <FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS">&#151;
</FONT>ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7
of the Form 10-K for a complete discussion of Alabama Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and
estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation, Contingent Obligations, and Unbilled Revenues.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123R, Share-Based Payments, was issued in December&nbsp;2004. This statement
requires that compensation cost relating to share-based payment transactions be recognized in
financial statements. That cost will be measured based on the grant date fair value of the equity
or liability instruments issued. In April




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">34
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">2005, the SEC amended the compliance dates for FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123R. For Alabama Power, this
statement is now effective beginning January&nbsp;1, 2006. Although the compensation expense
calculation required under the revised statement differs slightly, the impacts on the financial
statements are expected to be similar to the pro forma disclosures included in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Stock Options&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and in Note
(C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;47 (FIN 47), Accounting for Conditional Asset Retirement Obligations,
was issued in March&nbsp;2005. This interpretation requires that asset retirement obligations be
recorded when a legal obligation exists even though the timing and/or the method of settlement are
conditional on a future event. For Alabama Power, FIN 47 is effective no later than December&nbsp;31,
2005. Alabama Power is currently assessing the impact of FIN 47 on its balance sheet; however,
adoption is not currently expected to have a material impact on Alabama Power&#146;s income statement.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued Staff Position No.&nbsp;109-1 (FSP 109-1), Application of FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;109, Accounting for Income Taxes, to the Tax Deduction on Qualified Production
Activities provided by the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004, which requires that the generation
deduction for utilities be accounted for as a special tax deduction rather than as a tax rate
reduction. Alabama Power adopted FSP 109-1 in the first quarter of 2005 with no material impact on
its financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power&#146;s financial condition continued to be strong at March&nbsp;31, 2005. Net cash flows
from operating activities totaled $101.3&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2005, compared to $122.9
million for the first quarter 2004. The $21.6&nbsp;million decrease in 2005 resulted primarily from
an increase in cost and inventory of fuel. Those costs are recoverable in future periods and are
reflected on the balance sheets as under recovered regulatory clause revenues. Gross property
additions to utility plant were $197.6&nbsp;million in the first quarter 2005 and are included in the
balance sheets herein. The majority of funds needed for gross property additions since 2000 has
been provided from operating activities.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS -
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> &#151; </FONT> &#147;Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of
Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a description of Alabama Power&#146;s capital requirements
for its construction program, lease obligations, purchase commitments, and trust funding
requirements. Approximately $395&nbsp;million will be required by March&nbsp;31, 2006 for redemptions and
maturities of long-term debt.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In addition to the financing activities described below, Alabama Power plans to
obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources similar to those used in
the past. The amount, type, and timing of any financings &#151; if needed &#151; will depend upon
maintenance of adequate earnings, regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions, and other
factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Sources
of Capital&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, at March&nbsp;31, 2005 Alabama Power had $120
million of cash and cash equivalents, unused committed lines of credit of approximately $868
million (including $504


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">35
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">million of such lines which are dedicated to funding purchase obligations relating to variable rate
pollution control bonds), of which $643&nbsp;million will expire at various times during 2005, and an
extendible commercial
note program. Alabama Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to
expiration. See Note 6 to the financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Bank Credit
Arrangements&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information. Alabama Power may also meet
short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial
paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of Alabama Power and other
Southern Company subsidiaries. Alabama Power has regulatory authority for up to $1&nbsp;billion of
short-term borrowings. At March&nbsp;31, 2005, Alabama Power had no commercial paper or extendible
notes payable outstanding. Management believes that the need for working capital can be adequately
met by issuing commercial paper or utilizing lines of credit without maintaining large cash
balances.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in payment
schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are contracts that could
require collateral &#150; but not accelerated payment &#150; in the event of a credit rating change to below
investment grade. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity purchases and sales,
fixed-price physical gas purchases, and agreements covering interest rate swaps. At March&nbsp;31,
2005, Alabama Power had no exposure under these types of contracts.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed materially
compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2004 reporting period. In addition, Alabama Power is not aware of
any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Alabama Power has limited exposure to market volatility in
interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks
relative to movements in electricity prices, Alabama Power enters into fixed-price contracts for
the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market and, to a lesser
extent, similar contracts for gas purchases. Alabama Power has also implemented a retail fuel
hedging program at the instruction of the Alabama PSC. The fair value of derivative energy
contracts at March&nbsp;31, 2005 was as follows:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In March&nbsp;2005, Alabama Power issued $250&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;DD 5.65% Senior Notes due March&nbsp;15,
2035. The proceeds from the sale were used to repay a portion of Alabama Power&#146;s outstanding
short-term indebtedness and for other general corporate purposes, including Alabama Power&#146;s
continuing construction activities. Alabama Power settled an interest rate swap related to the
transaction at a cost of $21&nbsp;million, which was recorded in other comprehensive income. This cost
will be amortized over a 30-year period.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements and
contractual obligations, Alabama Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program to
retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if market
conditions permit.

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->

    <TD nowrap align="left" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000"><B>Liabilities and Stockholder's Equity</B></TD>

    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="2" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000"><B>2005</B></TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">The accompanying notes as they relate to Georgia Power are an integral part of these condensed financial statements.




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">42
</DIV>


<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B>


<DIV align="left">
<A name="106"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FIRST QUARTER 2005 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2004


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power operates as a vertically integrated utility providing electricity to retail customers
within its traditional service area located within the State of Georgia and to wholesale customers
in the Southeast. Many factors affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Georgia Power&#146;s
business of selling electricity. These factors include the ability to maintain a stable
regulatory environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to recover costs
related to growing demand and increasingly stringent environmental standards.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Georgia Power continues to focus on several key performance indicators. These indicators
include customer satisfaction, peak season equivalent forced outage rate, and return on equity.
For additional information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW
&#150; &#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the first quarter 2005
was $142.4&nbsp;million compared to $143.8&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2004. The slight
decrease was due to higher non-fuel operating expenses, partially offset by higher retail base
revenues resulting from the retail rate increase effective January&nbsp;1, 2005. For additional
information on the rate increase, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS
POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and Georgia PSC Matters &#150; Retail Rate Case&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the
Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the following:

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="50%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="80%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail revenues. </I>The chart below reflects the primary drivers of the 14.2% increase in
retail revenues in the first quarter 2005 compared to the same period in the prior year. Excluding
fuel cost recovery revenues, which generally do not affect net income, retail sales revenue
increased by $59.8&nbsp;million, or 8.5%, in the first quarter 2005 compared to the corresponding period
in 2004, primarily due to the retail rate increase effective January&nbsp;1, 2005. During the first
quarter 2005, kilowatt-hour energy sales to residential, commercial, and industrial customers were
down by 2.3%, up by 2.8%, and down by 2.5%, respectively, when compared to the same period in 2004.
Despite customer growth of 1.9% in the residential sector, the decrease in kilowatt-hour


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">43
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">energy sales in the first quarter 2005 was due to milder winter weather in 2005. The increase in
commercial kilowatt-hour energy sales in the first quarter 2005 can be attributed to sustained
economic strength and customer growth of 2.4% when compared to the same period in 2004. Industrial
kilowatt-hour energy sales were down primarily due to a 2.7% decrease in customers resulting
primarily from a reclassification of customers from industrial to commercial when compared to the
same period in 2004.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#150; non-affiliates. </I>During the first quarter 2005, sales for resale to
non-affiliates increased due to higher demand for energy by these customers as a result of new
contracts effective in January&nbsp;2005 when compared to the corresponding period in 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#150; affiliates and Purchased power expense &#150; affiliates. </I>Energy sales to and
purchases from affiliated companies within the Southern Company system will vary depending on
demand and the availability and cost of generating resources at each company. These sales and
purchases are made in accordance with the affiliated company interchange agreement, as approved by
the FERC. These transactions did not have a significant impact on earnings since this energy is
generally sold at marginal cost and energy purchases are generally offset by energy revenues
through Georgia Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause. Sales to affiliated companies decreased due to
an increase in Georgia Power&#146;s fuel costs relative to other Southern Company system generating
plants. Therefore, Georgia Power&#146;s generating plants were not called upon as often in the first
quarter 2005 to supply energy to affiliates. Purchased power from affiliates increased during the
first quarter 2005 when compared to the first quarter 2004 due to a 46.4% increase in the average
cost of fuel per kilowatt-hour and $17.6&nbsp;million of additional capacity expenses under PPAs with
Southern Power that went into effect in June&nbsp;2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense</I>. Fuel expense increased in the first quarter 2005 as a result of an increase in
the average cost of fuel per net kilowatt-hour generated of 12.7% when compared to the same period
in the prior year. These expenses do not have a significant impact on earnings since fuel expenses
are generally offset by fuel revenues through Georgia Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause. See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and Georgia PSC Matters &#150;
Retail Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#150; non-affiliates. </I>The decrease in purchased power from non-affiliates in the
first quarter 2005 when compared to the first quarter 2004 resulted from lower demand which caused
self-generation to be more economical. These expenses do not have a significant impact on earnings
since energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues through Georgia Power&#146;s fuel cost
recovery clause.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">44
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Maintenance expense. </I>In the first quarter 2005, maintenance expense increased primarily due
to an increase of $6.1&nbsp;million in scheduled fossil power production maintenance expense at Plants
Yates and Branch and an increase of $1.5&nbsp;million in scheduled distribution line maintenance when
compared to the same period in 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization expense. </I>Depreciation and amortization expense in the first
quarter 2005 compared to the same period in the prior year increased primarily due to the
expiration in 2004 of certain provisions in Georgia Power&#146;s three-year retail rate plan ending
December&nbsp;31, 2001 (2001 Retail Rate Plan). In accordance with the 2001 Retail Rate Plan, Georgia
Power amortized an accelerated cost recovery liability equally as a credit to amortization expense
and recognized new Georgia PSC-certified purchased power costs in rates evenly over the three years
ended December&nbsp;31, 2004. This treatment resulted in a credit to amortization expense of $47
million during the first quarter 2004. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power
under &#147;Retail Rate Orders&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Allowance for equity funds used during construction</I>. The first quarter 2005 increase in AFUDC
compared to the same period in the prior year relates primarily to construction of the McIntosh
combined cycle units 10 and 11. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under
&#147;Plant McIntosh Construction Project&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for further information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Georgia Power&#146;s future
earnings potential. The level of Georgia Power&#146;s future earnings depends on numerous factors that
affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Georgia Power&#146;s business of selling
electricity. These factors include Georgia Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to recover costs related to
growing demand and increasingly stringent environmental standards. Future earnings in the near
term will depend, in part, upon growth in energy sales which is subject to a number of factors.
These factors include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities, energy
conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and
the rate of economic growth in Georgia Power&#146;s service area. For additional information relating
to these issues, see BUSINESS &#150; The SOUTHERN System &#150; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For additional information, including information on
certain environmental litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS
POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Georgia Power under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;11, 2005, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit accepted Georgia Power&#146;s
petition for review of the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia&#146;s December&nbsp;15,
2004 order related to the Plant Wansley environmental litigation. Oral argument on that appeal has
not been scheduled. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Plant Wansley
Environmental Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information. The ultimate
outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">45
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Environmental Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The EPA issued the final Clean Air Interstate Rule on March&nbsp;10, 2005. The rule addresses sulfur
dioxide (SO<SUB>2</SUB>) and nitrogen oxide (NO<SUB>x</SUB>) emissions that contribute to
nonattainment of the eight-hour ozone and fine particulate matter National Ambient Air Quality
Standards. Twenty-eight eastern states, including the State of Georgia, are subject to the fine
particulate and/or the eight-hour ozone requirements set forth within the rule. The rule may
require additional reductions of NO<SUB>x</SUB> and/or SO<SUB>2</SUB> to be achieved by the
installation of additional controls at Georgia Power&#146;s facilities or through the purchase of
allowances. The impact of this final rule on Georgia Power will, however, depend on the development
and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced the final Clean Air Mercury Rule, selecting a
cap-and-trade approach to be implemented in two phases, 2010 and 2018. The rule sets a permanent
cap on emissions at the 2018 level and provides for an emissions allowance trading market. The
impact of this final rule on Georgia Power will depend on resolution of legal challenges and the
development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be determined
at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced plans to extend the deadline for issuance of final rules
addressing Best Available Retrofit Technology standards under its Regional Haze program until June
15, 2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The EPA published a proposed rule on April&nbsp;20, 2005 to approve redesignation of the Atlanta
metro area to &#147;attainment&#148; under the one-hour ozone standard.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FERC and Georgia PSC Matters</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and
Georgia PSC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority,&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for
measuring generation market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to
assess Southern Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory. Georgia
Power has authorization from the FERC to sell power to non-affiliates at market-based prices.
Georgia Power, through SCS as agent, also has FERC authority to make short-term opportunity
sales at market rates. Specific FERC approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based
contract with an affiliate. As directed by this order, on February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company
submitted additional information related to generation dominance in its retail service
territory. Any new market-based rate transactions in Southern Company&#146;s retail service
territory entered into after February&nbsp;27, 2005 will be subject to refund to the level of the
default cost-based rates, pending the outcome of the proceeding. In the event that the FERC&#146;s
default mitigation measures are ultimately applied, Georgia Power may be required to charge
cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales in the Southern Company retail service territory,
which may be lower than negotiated market-based rates. The impact of
such sales through March 31, 2005 is not material to Georgia
Power&#146;s net income. The final outcome of this matter will
depend on the form in which the final methodology for assessing generation market power and
mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Generation Interconnection Agreements</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and Georgia PSC
Matters &#150; Generation Interconnection Agreements&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for
information on the FERC&#146;s Order 2003 related to standardization of generation interconnection
agreements and procedures. The FERC has indicated that Order 2003, which was effective January&nbsp;20,
2004, is to be






<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">46
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">applied prospectively to interconnection agreements. Subsidiaries of Tenaska, Inc., as
counterparties to previously executed interconnection agreements with Georgia Power and another
Southern Company subsidiary, have filed complaints at the FERC requesting that the FERC modify the
agreements and that Georgia Power refund a total of $7.9&nbsp;million previously paid for
interconnection facilities, with interest. Georgia Power has opposed such relief, and the
proceedings are still pending. The impact of Order 2003 and its subsequent rehearings on Georgia
Power and the final results of these matters cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Retail Fuel Cost Recovery</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On February&nbsp;18, 2005, Georgia Power filed a request with the Georgia PSC for a fuel cost recovery
rate increase. The requested increase, representing an average annual increase in revenues of
approximately 11.8%, will allow for the recovery of fuel costs based on an estimate of future fuel
costs, as well as the collection of the existing under recovery of fuel costs. The Georgia PSC may
require that this existing under recovery be collected over a period greater than twelve months.
Georgia Power&#146;s under recovered fuel costs as of March&nbsp;31, 2005 totaled $455.4&nbsp;million. Hearings
before the Georgia PSC were held in April&nbsp;2005. A final decision from the Georgia PSC is expected
in May&nbsp;2005 with the new fuel rate effective June 1. The final outcome of the filing cannot be
determined at this time. For additional information on Georgia Power&#146;s current fuel cost recovery
rate, see Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K and Note (I)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of
business. In addition, Georgia Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive governmental
regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and
claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, and citizen enforcement of
environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout the United States. In particular,
personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become
more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such litigation against Georgia Power cannot be predicted at
this time; however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from such
current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on Georgia Power&#146;s financial statements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various
contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings potential.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Georgia Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could produce estimates
that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements. Also see
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting
Policies and Estimates&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete discussion of
Georgia Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation,
Contingent Obligations, and Unbilled Revenues.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">47
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123R, Share-Based Payments, was issued in December&nbsp;2004. This statement
requires that compensation cost relating to share-based payment transactions be recognized in
financial statements. That cost will be measured based on the grant date fair value of the equity
or liability instruments issued. In April&nbsp;2005, the SEC amended the compliance dates for FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;123R. For Georgia Power, this statement is now effective beginning January&nbsp;1, 2006.
Although the compensation expense calculation required under the revised statement differs
slightly, the impacts on Georgia Power&#146;s financial statements are expected to be similar to the pro
forma disclosures included in Note 1 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Stock
Options&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and in Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;47 (FIN 47), Accounting for Conditional Asset Retirement Obligations,
was issued in March&nbsp;2005. This interpretation requires that asset retirement obligations be
recorded when a legal obligation exists even though the timing and/or the method of settlement are
conditional on a future event. For Georgia Power, FIN 47 is effective no later than December&nbsp;31,
2005. Georgia Power is currently assessing the impact of FIN 47 on its balance sheet; however,
adoption is not currently expected to have a material impact on Georgia Power&#146;s income statement.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued Staff Position No.&nbsp;109-1 (FSP 109-1), Application of FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;109, Accounting for Income Taxes, to the Tax Deduction on Qualified Production
Activities provided by the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004, which requires that the generation
deduction for utilities be accounted for as a special tax deduction rather than as a tax rate
reduction. Georgia Power adopted FSP 109-1 in the first quarter of 2005 with no material impact on
its financial statements.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Over the last several years, Georgia Power&#146;s financial condition has remained stable. Net
cash flow from operating activities totaled $14.2&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2005, compared to
$118.4&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2004. The decrease of $104.2&nbsp;million in 2005 is primarily the
result of higher fuel costs, which are recoverable in future periods and are reflected in the
balance sheets as under recovered regulatory clause revenues. During the first quarter 2005, gross
property additions were $202.4&nbsp;million. These additions were primarily related to the construction
of Plant McIntosh Units 10 and 11, transmission and distribution facilities, and purchases of
nuclear fuel and equipment to comply with environmental standards. The majority of funds for these
additions and other capital requirements were derived primarily from operating activities and
financing activities. See Georgia Power&#146;s Condensed Statements of Cash Flows herein for further
details.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> &#150;</FONT> &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Georgia Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, lease
obligations, purchase commitments, and trust funding requirements. Approximately $353&nbsp;million will
be required by March&nbsp;31, 2006 for redemptions and maturities of long-term debt.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources
similar to those used in the past, including funds from operations and new security issuances. The
amount, type, and





<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">48
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">timing of additional security issuances, if needed, will depend upon maintenance of adequate
earnings, regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions, and other factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Georgia Power
in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At March&nbsp;31, 2005, Georgia Power&#146;s current liabilities exceeded current assets because of the
continued use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet cash needs, which can fluctuate
significantly due to the seasonality of the business. To meet short-term cash needs and
contingencies, Georgia Power had at March&nbsp;31, 2005 approximately $9&nbsp;million of cash and cash
equivalents and $773&nbsp;million of unused credit arrangements with banks. Of these facilities, $423
million expire in 2005 and contain provisions allowing two-year term loans executable at
expiration; and the remaining $350&nbsp;million expire in 2007. Georgia Power expects to renew its
credit facilities, as needed, prior to expiration. These unused credit arrangements provide
liquidity support to Georgia Power&#146;s obligations with respect to variable rate pollution control
bonds and commercial paper. Georgia Power may also meet short-term cash needs through a Southern
Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial notes at
the request and for the benefit of Georgia Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At March
31, 2005, Georgia Power had $531.4&nbsp;million of commercial paper and $16.6&nbsp;million of extendible
commercial notes outstanding. Management believes that the need for working capital can be
adequately met by utilizing commercial paper programs and lines of credit without maintaining large
cash balances.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in payment
schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain contracts
that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit rating change
to BBB- or Baa3 or below. Generally, collateral may be provided for by a Southern Company
guaranty, letter of credit, or cash. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity
purchases and sales. At March&nbsp;31, 2005, the maximum potential collateral requirements at a BBB- or
Baa3 rating were approximately $8&nbsp;million. The maximum potential collateral requirements at a
rating below BBB- or Baa3 were approximately $247&nbsp;million. Georgia Power is also party to certain
derivative agreements that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a
credit rating change to below investment grade. These agreements are primarily for natural gas
price and interest rate risk management activities. At March&nbsp;31, 2005, Georgia Power had no
material exposure related to these agreements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not
changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2004 reporting period. In addition, Georgia
Power is not aware of any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in
the near term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Georgia Power has limited exposure to market volatility in
interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks
relative to movements in electricity prices, Georgia Power enters into fixed-price contracts for
the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market and, to a lesser
extent, similar contracts for gas purchases. Georgia Power has also implemented a fuel hedging
program at the instruction of the Georgia PSC.




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">49
</DIV>

to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In January&nbsp;2005, Georgia Power issued $250&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;X 5.70% Senior Notes due January&nbsp;15,
2045. Proceeds from the sale were used to repay at maturity $250&nbsp;million principal amount of
Series&nbsp;L Floating Rate Senior Notes in February&nbsp;2005.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April&nbsp;2005, Georgia Power incurred obligations in connection with the issuance of $85
million 4.75% pollution control revenue bonds. Proceeds from the sale will be used to repay
obligations in connection with $85&nbsp;million of 5.40% pollution control revenue bonds in May&nbsp;2005.
Also in April, Georgia Power issued $125&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;Y 5.80% Senior Notes due April&nbsp;15, 2035.
Proceeds were used to repay a portion of Georgia Power&#146;s short-term indebtedness and for other
corporate purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April&nbsp;2005, Georgia Power entered into an interest rate swap designed to mitigate its
exposure to adverse interest rate movements with respect to the anticipated Series&nbsp;Y Senior Note
issuance. In connection with the issuance of such senior notes, Georgia Power terminated the swap
at a fair value loss of $0.3&nbsp;million, which will be amortized over a 10-year period.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements and
contractual obligations, Georgia Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program to
retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if market
conditions permit.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">50
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">55

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B>


<DIV align="left">
<A name="107"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FIRST QUARTER 2005 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2004



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power operates as a vertically integrated utility providing electricity to customers within
its traditional service area located in northwest Florida and to wholesale customers in the
Southeast. Prices for electricity provided by Gulf Power to retail customers are set by the
Florida PSC. Many factors affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Gulf Power&#146;s business of selling electricity. These factors include the ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to recover costs related to
growing demand and increasingly stringent environmental standards.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gulf Power continues to focus on several key performance indicators. These indicators include
customer satisfaction, peak season equivalent forced outage rate, and return on equity. For
additional information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; OVERVIEW -
&#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the first quarter 2005 was $14.6
million compared to $16.8&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2004. First quarter 2005 net
income decreased by $2.2&nbsp;million, or 13.0%, primarily due to a reduction in retail revenue caused
by milder winter weather, as compared to the same period in 2004.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the following:

<DIV align="center">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail revenues. </I>The chart below reflects the primary drivers of the 1.7% decrease in retail
revenues in the first quarter 2005 compared to the same period in the prior year. Excluding
revenues related to fuel and other cost recovery, which do not affect net income, retail revenues
decreased by $4.3&nbsp;million, or 4.5%, for the first quarter 2005 as compared to the corresponding
period in 2004. Energy sales to residential, commercial, and industrial customers were lower by
8.6%, 2.7%, and 2.8%, respectively, in the first quarter 2005 as compared to the same period in
2004 primarily due to milder winter weather conditions.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">56
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Details of retail revenues are as follows:

<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#150; affiliates and Purchased power expense </I>&#150; <I>affiliates</I>. Revenues from sales
for resale to affiliates and purchases of energy from affiliates will vary depending on demand and
the availability and cost of generating resources at each company within the Southern Company
system. These affiliate sales and purchases are made in accordance with the affiliate company
interchange agreement as approved by the FERC. These transactions do not have a significant impact
on earnings since this energy is generally sold at marginal cost and energy purchases are generally
offset by energy revenues through Gulf Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery mechanism. The increase in sales
for resale to affiliates is due to increased sales of available generation to affiliate companies
at a higher unit cost resulting from higher fuel prices. The decrease in purchased power from
affiliates is the result of a decrease in the demand for purchased power due to increased
self-generation, which was more economical.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>In the first quarter 2005, fuel expense was higher than the same period in 2004
primarily due to a greater percentage of generation needs supplied by higher priced natural gas
units as well as a 10.7% increase in coal prices and a 12.8% increase in natural gas prices. Since
energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues through Gulf Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery
mechanism, these expenses do not have a material impact on net income.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power expense &#150; non-affiliates. </I>The decrease in the first quarter 2005, as compared
to the corresponding period in 2004, is primarily the result of an increase in available Southern
Company system generation. Since energy expenses are generally offset by revenues through Gulf
Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery mechanism, these expenses do not have a significant impact on net
income.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operations and maintenance expense</I>. The increase in other operations expense during the
first quarter 2005 is primarily due to increased employee benefit expenses as compared to the same
period in 2004. The first quarter 2005 increase in maintenance expense from the same period in the
prior year reflects an increase in scheduled maintenance performed on power generation and
distribution facilities in 2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Income tax expense. </I>The decrease in income taxes of $2.4&nbsp;million, or 23.7%, in the first
quarter 2005 is primarily due to the $4.5&nbsp;million reduction in pretax net income as compared to the
same period in 2004.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">57
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Gulf Power&#146;s future
earnings potential. The level of Gulf Power&#146;s future earnings depends on numerous factors that
affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Gulf Power&#146;s business of selling
electricity. These factors include the ability of Gulf Power to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to recover costs related to
growing demand and increasingly stringent environmental standards. Future earnings in the near
term will depend, in part, upon growth in energy sales, which is subject to a number of factors.
These factors include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities, energy
conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and
the rate of economic growth in Gulf Power&#146;s service area. For additional information relating to
these issues, see <FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS">BUSINESS </FONT>&#150; The SOUTHERN System<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the
Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For additional information, including information on
certain environmental litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS
POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements
of Gulf Power under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The EPA issued the final Clean Air Interstate Rule on March&nbsp;10, 2005. The rule addresses
sulfur dioxide (SO<SUB>2</SUB>) and nitrogen oxide (NO<SUB>x</SUB>) emissions that contribute to
nonattainment of the eight-hour ozone and fine particulate matter National Ambient Air Quality
Standards. Twenty-eight eastern states, including the States of Georgia, Florida, and Mississippi,
are subject to the fine particulate and/or the eight-hour ozone requirements set forth within the
rule. The rule may require additional reductions of NO<SUB>x</SUB> and/or SO<SUB>2</SUB> to be
achieved by the installation of additional controls at Gulf Power&#146;s facilities or through the
purchase of allowances. The impact of this final rule on Gulf Power will, however, depend on the
development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be determined
at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced the final Clean Air Mercury Rule, selecting a
cap-and-trade approach to be implemented in two phases, 2010 and 2018. The rule sets a permanent
cap on emissions at the 2018 level and provides for an emissions allowance trading market. The
impact of this final rule on Gulf Power will depend on resolution of legal challenges and the
development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be determined
at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced plans to extend the deadline for issuance of final rules
addressing Best Available Retrofit Technology standards under its Regional Haze program until June
15, 2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FERC Matters</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and
Florida PSC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for measuring generation market
power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to assess Southern Company&#146;s




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">58
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">generation dominance within its retail service territory. Gulf Power has authorization from the
FERC to sell power to non-affiliates at market-based prices. Gulf Power, through SCS as agent,
also has FERC authority to make short-term opportunity sales at market rates. Specific FERC
approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based contract with an affiliate. As
directed by this order, on February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company submitted additional information
related to generation dominance in its retail service territory. Any new market-based rate
transactions in Southern Company&#146;s retail service territory entered into after February&nbsp;27, 2005
will be subject to refund to the level of the default cost-based rates, pending the outcome of
the proceeding. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures are ultimately applied
Gulf Power may be required to charge cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales in the
Southern Company retail service territory, which may be lower than negotiated market-based
rates. The impact of such sales through March 31, 2005 is not
material to Gulf Power&#146;s net income. The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in which the final methodology
for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot
be determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Generation Interconnection Agreements</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and Florida PSC
Matters &#150; Generation Interconnection Agreements&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for
information on the FERC&#146;s Order 2003 related to standardization of generation interconnection
agreements and procedures. The FERC has indicated that Order 2003, which was effective January&nbsp;20,
2004, is to be applied prospectively to interconnection agreements. Subsidiaries of Tenaska, Inc.,
as counterparties to three previously executed interconnection agreements with other Southern
Company subsidiaries, have filed complaints at the FERC requesting that the FERC modify the
agreements and that Southern Company refund amounts previously paid for interconnection facilities,
with interest. Gulf Power has also received similar requests from other entities totaling $6.6
million. Gulf Power has opposed such relief, and the proceedings are still pending. The impact of
Order 2003 and its subsequent rehearings on Gulf Power and the final results of these matters
cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Storm Damage Cost Recovery</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Hurricane Ivan hit Gulf Power&#146;s service territory in September&nbsp;2004. In March&nbsp;2005, the Florida
PSC approved a Stipulation and Settlement between Gulf Power, the Office of Public Counsel for
the State of Florida, and the Florida Industrial Power Users Group which allows Gulf Power to
recover the retail portion of $51.7&nbsp;million, the projected reserve deficiency, plus interest and
revenue taxes, from customers over a 24-month period beginning in April&nbsp;2005. In connection
with the Stipulation, Gulf Power has agreed that it will not seek any additional increase in its
base rates and charges to become effective on or before March&nbsp;1, 2007. See &#147;Storm Damage Cost
Recovery&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Other Matters</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of
business. In addition, Gulf Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive governmental
regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and
claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, and citizen enforcement of
environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout the United States. In particular,
personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become
more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such litigation against Gulf Power cannot be predicted at
this time; however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from such
current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on Gulf Power&#146;s financial statements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various
contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings potential.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">59
</DIV>
