<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Gulf Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could produce estimates
that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements. Also see
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting
Policies and Estimates&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete discussion of Gulf
Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation,
Contingent Obligations, and Unbilled Revenues.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123R, Share-Based Payments, was issued in December&nbsp;2004. This statement
requires that compensation cost relating to share-based payment transactions be recognized in
financial statements. That cost will be measured based on the grant date fair value of the equity
or liability instruments issued. In April&nbsp;2005, the SEC amended the compliance dates for FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;123R. For Gulf Power, this statement is now effective beginning January&nbsp;1, 2006.
Although the compensation expense calculation required under the revised statement differs
slightly, the impacts on Gulf Power&#146;s financial statements are expected to be similar to the pro
forma disclosures included in Note 1 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Stock
Options&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and in Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;47 (FIN 47), Accounting for Conditional Asset Retirement Obligations,
was issued in March&nbsp;2005. This interpretation requires that asset retirement obligations be
recorded when a legal obligation exists even though the timing and/or the method of settlement are
conditional on a future event. For Gulf Power, FIN 47 is effective no later than December&nbsp;31,
2005. Gulf Power is currently assessing the impact of FIN 47 on its balance sheet; however,
adoption is not currently expected to have a material impact on Gulf Power&#146;s income statement.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued Staff Position No.&nbsp;109-1 (FSP 109-1), Application of FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;109, Accounting for Income Taxes, to the Tax Deduction on Qualified Production
Activities provided by the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004, which requires that the generation
deduction for utilities be accounted for as a special tax deduction rather than as a tax rate
reduction. Gulf Power adopted FSP 109-1 in the first quarter of 2005 with no material impact on
its financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power&#146;s financial condition continued to be strong at March&nbsp;31, 2005. Net cash flow from
operating activities totaled $41.1&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2005, compared to $56.5&nbsp;million
for the first quarter 2004. The $15.4&nbsp;million decrease in 2005 resulted primarily from payments
related to storm damage from Hurricane Ivan. Gross property additions to utility plant were
$34.1&nbsp;million in the first quarter 2005. Funds for Gulf Power&#146;s property additions were
provided by operating activities, capital contributions, and other financing activities. See
the Condensed Statements of Cash Flows for additional information.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">60
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> -</FONT> &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Gulf Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, lease obligations,
purchase commitments, and trust funding requirements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources
similar to those used in the past. These sources include cash flows from operating activities and
issuances of unsecured debt, preferred securities or stock, and pollution control bonds issued for
Gulf Power&#146;s benefit by public authorities. The amount, type, and timing of any future financings,
if needed, will depend upon maintenance of adequate earnings, regulatory approval, prevailing
market conditions, and other factors. See<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K
for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At March&nbsp;31, 2005, Gulf Power&#146;s current liabilities exceeded current assets because of the
continued use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet cash needs, which can fluctuate
significantly due to the seasonality of the business. To meet short-term cash needs and
contingencies, Gulf Power has various internal and external sources of liquidity. At March&nbsp;31,
2005, Gulf Power had approximately $37.4&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and $56.3&nbsp;million of
unused committed lines of credit with banks that expire in 2005. Gulf Power expects to renew its
credit facilities, as needed, prior to expiration. In addition, Gulf Power has substantial cash
flow from operating activities. The credit arrangements provide liquidity support to Gulf Power&#146;s
obligations with respect to variable rate pollution control bonds and commercial paper. Gulf Power
may also meet short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and
sell commercial paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of Gulf
Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At March&nbsp;31, 2005, Gulf Power had no commercial
paper or extendible commercial notes outstanding.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in payment
schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain contracts
that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit rating change
to BBB- or Baa3 or below. Generally, collateral may be provided for by a Southern Company
guaranty, letter of credit, or cash. These contracts are primarily for the sale of electric
capacity. At March&nbsp;31, 2005, the maximum potential collateral requirements at a BBB- or Baa3
rating were approximately $5&nbsp;million. The maximum potential collateral requirements at a rating
below BBB- or Baa3 were approximately $10&nbsp;million. Gulf Power is also party to certain derivative
agreements that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a credit rating
change to below investment grade. These agreements are primarily for natural gas price and
interest rate risk management activities. At March&nbsp;31, 2005, Gulf Power had no exposure under
these agreements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed materially
compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2004 reporting period. In addition, Gulf Power is not aware of any
facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">61
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulation, Gulf Power has limited exposure to market volatility in
interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks
relative to movements in electricity prices, Gulf Power enters into fixed-price contracts for
purchase of coal supplies, the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity
market, and, to a lesser extent, similar contracts for gas purchases. Gulf Power has received
approval from the Florida PSC to recover prudently incurred costs related to its fuel
hedging program through the fuel cost recovery mechanism. The fair value of derivative energy
contracts at March&nbsp;31, 2005 was as follows:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price
Risk&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under
&#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for further information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power did not issue or redeem any long-term securities in the first quarter of 2005. In
addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements and contractual
obligations, Gulf Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program to retire
higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if market conditions
permit.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent to March&nbsp;31, 2005, Gulf Power repaid $30&nbsp;million of a $50&nbsp;million short-term
borrowing incurred in the fourth quarter 2004.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">62
</DIV>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B>


<DIV align="left">
<A name="108"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FIRST QUARTER 2005 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2004



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power operates as a vertically integrated utility providing electricity to retail
customers within its traditional service area located within the State of Mississippi and to
wholesale customers in the Southeast. Many factors affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks
of Mississippi Power&#146;s business of selling electricity. These factors include the ability
to maintain a stable regulatory environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs,
and to recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stringent environmental standards.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mississippi Power continues to focus on several key performance indicators. In recognition
that Mississippi Power&#146;s long-term financial success is dependent upon how well it satisfies its
customers&#146; needs, Mississippi Power&#146;s retail base rate mechanism, PEP, includes performance
indicators that directly tie customer service indicators to Mississippi Power&#146;s allowed return. In
addition to the PEP performance indicators, Mississippi Power focuses on other performance
measures, including broader measures of customer satisfaction, return on equity, and peak season
equivalent forced outage rate. For additional information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW &#151; &#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of
the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the first quarter 2005 of
$16.9&nbsp;million decreased $372,000, or 2.1%, from $17.3&nbsp;million for the same period of 2004.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the following:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail revenues. </I>The chart below reflects the primary drivers of the 2.5% increase in retail
revenues in the first quarter 2005 compared to the same period in the prior year. Retail revenues
for the first quarter 2005 increased when compared to the same period in 2004 primarily as a result of a $5.6&nbsp;million increase
in fuel and other cost recovery revenues, which generally do not have an effect on income. Retail
revenues, excluding fuel revenues, for the first quarter 2005 from residential and commercial
customers decreased 3.2% and 6.0%, respectively, primarily as a result of milder weather. Retail
revenues, excluding fuel revenues, for the first quarter 2005 from industrial customers remained
consistent compared to the same period in 2004.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">68

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale </I>&#150; <I>non-affiliates. </I>The decrease in sales for resale to non-affiliates in the
first quarter 2005 as compared to the same period in 2004 is primarily due to fewer opportunities
in the wholesale market as a result of higher fuel prices.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale </I>&#150; <I>affiliates and Purchased power expense </I>&#150; <I>affiliates</I>. Revenues from sales
for resale to affiliates, as well as purchases of energy from affiliates, will vary depending on
demand and the availability and cost of generating resources at each company within the Southern
Company system. These affiliate sales and purchases are made in accordance with the affiliate
company interchange agreement approved by the FERC. These transactions do not have a significant
impact on earnings since the energy is generally sold at marginal cost and energy purchases are
generally offset by energy revenues through Mississippi Power&#146;s retail and wholesale fuel cost
recovery clauses. The increase in sales for resale to affiliates and the decrease in purchased
power from affiliates are a result of Mississippi Power&#146;s more economical generating costs when
compared to others.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>In the first quarter 2005, fuel expense increased when compared to the same
period in 2004 as a result of a 2.6% increase in generation and a 18.0% increase in the cost of
coal, oil, gas, and emission allowances. Since energy expenses are generally offset by energy
revenues through Mississippi Power&#146;s retail and wholesale fuel cost recovery clauses, these
expenses do not have a significant impact on earnings.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power expense &#150; non-affiliates</I>. In the first quarter 2005, purchased power from
non-affiliates decreased due to increased self-generation that resulted from higher generating unit
availability during the first quarter 2005 as compared to the same period in 2004, when more
scheduled maintenance outages occurred.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other
operations expense</I>. In the first quarter 2005, other operations expense increased primarily
due to a $1.6&nbsp;million increase in employee and retiree benefit
expense as a result of higher employee medical expenses and updated
actuarial studies for pension and postretirement benefits for 2005,
an increase in lease expense of approximately $0.6&nbsp;million due
to higher interest rates on the embedded variable rate debt, a
$0.4&nbsp;million increase in expenses related to customer accounts,
and a $0.4&nbsp;million increase in legal and accounting expenses.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization. </I>The first quarter 2005 decrease in depreciation and
amortization expense when compared to the same period in 2004 is primarily the result of
$6.3&nbsp;million in amortization of the regulatory liability related to Plant Daniel capacity recorded in
2005 as approved by the Mississippi PSC. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi
Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Taxes other than income taxes. </I>The increase in taxes other than income taxes for the first
quarter 2005 as compared to the same period in 2004 is a result of higher property taxes.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">69
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Mississippi Power&#146;s
future earnings potential. The level of Mississippi Power&#146;s future earnings depends on numerous
factors that affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Mississippi Power&#146;s business of selling electricity. These factors include the ability of Mississippi Power to
maintain a stable regulatory environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs,
and to recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stringent environmental standards.
Future earnings in the near term will depend, in part, upon growth in energy sales, which is
subject to a number of factors. These factors include weather, competition, new energy contracts
with neighboring utilities, energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity,
the price elasticity of demand, and the rate of economic growth in Mississippi Power&#146;s service
area. For additional information relating to these issues, see BUSINESS &#151; The SOUTHERN System -
&#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of
Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For additional information, including information on
certain environmental litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS
POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The EPA issued the final Clean Air Interstate Rule on March&nbsp;10, 2005. The rule addresses
sulfur dioxide (SO<SUB>2</SUB>) and nitrogen oxide (NO<SUB>x</SUB>) emissions that contribute to
nonattainment of the eight-hour ozone and fine particulate matter National Ambient Air Quality
Standards. Twenty-eight eastern states, including the States of Alabama and Mississippi, are
subject to the fine particulate and/or the eight-hour ozone requirements set forth within the rule.
The rule may require additional reductions of NO<SUB>x</SUB> and/or SO<SUB>2</SUB> to be achieved
by the installation of additional controls at Mississippi Power&#146;s facilities or through the
purchase of allowances. The impact of this final rule on Mississippi Power will, however, depend
on the development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be
determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced the final Clean Air Mercury Rule, selecting a
cap-and-trade approach to be implemented in two phases, 2010 and 2018. The rule sets a permanent
cap on emissions at the 2018 level and provides for an emissions allowance trading market. The
impact of this final rule on Mississippi Power will depend on resolution of legal challenges and
the development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be
determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced plans to extend the deadline for issuance of final rules
addressing Best Available Retrofit Technology standards under its Regional Haze program until June
15, 2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FERC and Mississippi PSC Matters</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and
Mississippi PSC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3
to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis
for measuring generation market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to assess Southern
Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory. Mississippi Power has
authorization





<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">70
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">from the FERC to sell power to non-affiliates at market-based prices. Mississippi Power,
through SCS as agent, also has FERC authority to make short-term opportunity sales at market
rates. Specific FERC approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based contract with an
affiliate. As directed by this order, on February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company submitted
additional information related to generation dominance in its retail service territory. Any new
market-based rate transactions in Southern Company&#146;s retail service territory entered into after
February&nbsp;27, 2005 will be subject to refund to the level of the default cost-based rates,
pending the outcome of the proceeding. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures
are ultimately applied Mississippi Power may be required to charge cost-based rates for certain
wholesale sales in the Southern Company retail service territory, which may be lower than
negotiated market-based rates. The impact of such sales through March
31, 2005 is not material to Mississippi Power&#146;s net income. The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in which
the final methodology for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be
ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Environmental Compliance
Overview Plan&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information on the ECO Plan. Mississippi
Power&#146;s ECO Plan annual filing for 2005 was approved by the Mississippi PSC at the conclusion of
the ECO Plan hearings on April&nbsp;5, 2005. An order is forthcoming. The result will be a slight
increase in rates effective May&nbsp;2005. Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other
environmental regulations could affect earnings if such costs cannot continue to be recovered.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Other Matters</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of
business. In addition, Mississippi Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive
governmental regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over
environmental issues and claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, and
citizen enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout the United
States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous
materials have become more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such litigation against Mississippi
Power cannot be predicted at this time; however, management does not anticipate that the
liabilities, if any, arising from such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on
Mississippi Power&#146;s financial statements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various
contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings potential.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1
to the financial statements of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of
these policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Mississippi Power&#146;s
results of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could
produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements.
Also see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical
Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete
discussion of Mississippi Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric
Utility Regulation, Contingent Obligations, Unbilled Revenues, and Plant Daniel Operating Lease.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">71
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123R, Share-Based Payments, was issued in December&nbsp;2004. This statement
requires that compensation cost relating to share-based payment transactions be recognized in
financial statements. That cost will be measured based on the grant date fair value of the equity
or liability instruments issued. In April&nbsp;2005, the SEC amended the compliance dates for FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;123R. For Mississippi Power, this statement is now effective beginning January&nbsp;1,
2006. Although the compensation expense calculation required under the revised statement differs
slightly, the impacts on Mississippi Power&#146;s financial statements are expected to be similar to the
pro forma disclosures included in Note 1 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under
&#147;Stock Options&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements
herein.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;47 (FIN 47), Accounting for Conditional Asset Retirement Obligations,
was issued in March&nbsp;2005. This interpretation requires that asset retirement obligations be
recorded when a legal obligation exists even though the timing and/or the method of settlement are
conditional on a future event. For Mississippi Power, FIN 47 is effective no later than December
31, 2005. Mississippi Power is currently assessing the impact of FIN 47 on its balance sheet;
however, adoption is not currently expected to have a material impact on Mississippi Power&#146;s income
statement.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued Staff Position No.&nbsp;109-1 (FSP 109-1), Application of FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;109, Accounting for Income Taxes, to the Tax Deduction on Qualified Production
Activities provided by the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004, which requires that the generation
deduction for utilities be accounted for as a special tax deduction rather than as a tax rate
reduction. Mississippi Power adopted FSP 109-1 in the first quarter of 2005 with no material
impact on its financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s financial condition continued to be strong at March&nbsp;31, 2005. Net cash flow
provided from operating activities totaled $7.5&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2005, compared to
net cash flow used for operating activities of $10.9&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2004. The
$18.4&nbsp;million increase in 2005 resulted primarily from fuel and Energy Cost Management clause
collections. Gross property additions to utility plant were $14.2&nbsp;million in the first quarter
2005. The majority of funds needed for gross property additions since 2000 has been provided
from operating activities.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Mississippi Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, lease
obligations, purchase commitments, and trust funding requirements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In addition to the financing activities described herein, Mississippi Power plans to obtain the
funds required for construction and other purposes from sources similar to those used in the past.
The amount, type, and timing of any financings, if needed, will depend upon maintenance of adequate
earnings, regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions, and other factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Mississippi
Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">72
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At March&nbsp;31, 2005, Mississippi Power&#146;s current liabilities exceeded current assets because of
the continued use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet cash needs, which can fluctuate
significantly due to the seasonality of the business. To meet short-term cash needs and
contingencies, Mississippi Power had at March&nbsp;31, 2005 approximately $3.9&nbsp;million of cash and cash
equivalents and $100.5&nbsp;million of unused committed credit arrangements with banks that expire in
2005. Approximately $38&nbsp;million of these credit arrangements contain provisions allowing two-year
term loans executable at expiration. Mississippi Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as
needed, prior to expiration. The credit arrangements provide liquidity support to Mississippi
Power&#146;s obligations with respect to variable rate pollution control bonds and commercial paper.
Mississippi Power may also meet short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary
organized to issue and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and for
the benefit of Mississippi Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At March&nbsp;31, 2005,
Mississippi Power had $19.9&nbsp;million in outstanding notes payable. Management believes that the
need for working capital can be adequately met by utilizing lines of credit without maintaining
large cash balances.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Off-Balance Sheet
Financing Arrangements&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 7 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under
&#147;Operating Leases&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information related to Mississippi Power&#146;s lease
of a combined cycle generating facility at Plant Daniel.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in
payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. Mississippi Power is
party to certain derivative agreements that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in
the event of a credit rating change to below investment grade. These agreements are primarily for
natural gas price risk management activities. At March&nbsp;31, 2005, Mississippi
Power had no exposure under these agreements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed
materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2004 reporting period. In addition, Mississippi Power is
not aware of any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near
term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulation, Mississippi Power has limited exposure to market volatility
in interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks
relative to movements in electricity prices, Mississippi Power enters into fixed-price contracts
for the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market. Mississippi
Power has also implemented retail fuel hedging programs at the instruction of the Mississippi PSC
and wholesale fuel hedging programs under agreements with wholesale customers.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">73
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power did not issue or redeem any long-term securities during the first quarter of
2005. In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements and
contractual obligations, Mississippi Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program
to retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if market
conditions permit.

<DIV align="left">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>CONDENSED STATEMENTS OF
INCOME (UNAUDITED)</B>


<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="80%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">The accompanying notes as they relate to Savannah Electric are an integral part of these condensed
financial statements.

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B>

<DIV align="left">

</DIV>
<div align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>CONDENSED BALANCE
SHEETS (UNAUDITED)</b></div>


<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="80%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>

</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B>


<DIV align="left">
<A name="109"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FIRST QUARTER 2005 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2004



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric operates as a vertically integrated utility providing electricity to retail
customers within its traditional service area of southeastern Georgia. Many factors affect the
opportunities, challenges, and risks of Savannah Electric&#146;s business of selling
electricity. These factors include the ability to maintain a stable regulatory environment, to
achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to recover costs related to growing demand
and increasingly stringent environmental standards.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Savannah Electric continues to focus on several key performance indicators. These indicators
include customer satisfaction, peak season equivalent forced outage rate, and return on equity.
For additional information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW
&#150; &#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Savannah Electric in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Note 9 to the financial statements of Savannah Electric in Item 8
of the Form 10-K for information regarding Savannah Electric&#146;s
restatement of its financial statements for the quarter ended March
31, 2004 as the result of errors in the estimate of unbilled revenues
for the period.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the first quarter 2005 was
$1.0&nbsp;million compared to $2.8&nbsp;million for the corresponding period of 2004. Earnings decreased by
$1.8&nbsp;million, or 64.0%, in the first quarter 2005, primarily due to higher operating expenses,
partially offset by higher operating revenues.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the following:

<DIV align="center">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail revenues</I>. The chart below reflects the primary drivers of the 25.9% increase in retail
revenues in the first quarter 2005 compared to the same period in the prior year. Excluding fuel
cost recovery revenues, which do not affect net income, retail revenue increased by $0.2&nbsp;million,
or 0.4%, in the first quarter 2005 when compared to the corresponding period in 2004. The first
quarter 2005 increase in retail revenue is mainly attributed to a slight increase in residential
and commercial customer growth.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale </I>&#150; <I>non-affiliates. </I>In the first quarter 2005, revenues from sales for resale
to non-affiliates were lower primarily due to less opportunity in the market as a result of higher
fuel prices. These transactions had no significant effect on net income.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#150; affiliates and Purchased power expense </I>&#150; <I>affiliates. </I>Energy sales to and
purchases from affiliated companies within the Southern Company system will vary from period to
period depending on demand and the availability and cost of generating resources at each company.
These sales and purchases are made in accordance with the affiliated company interchange agreement,
as approved by the FERC. Sales for resale to affiliates decreased in the first quarter 2005 when
compared to the corresponding period in 2004 due to higher fuel prices. Purchased power from
affiliates increased during the first quarter 2005 due to a 20.5% increase in energy purchases as a
result of scheduled maintenance on Savannah Electric&#146;s largest
coal units and an increase in the
average cost of fuel per net kilowatt-hour. These transactions do not have a significant impact on
earnings since energy is sold at marginal cost and energy purchases are generally offset by energy
revenues through Savannah Electric&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>Fuel expense increased in the first quarter 2005 primarily as a result of
higher energy prices and an adjustment in 2004 as a result of billing credits relating to the Plant
McIntosh combustion turbines, which reduced 2004 fuel expense. Since fuel expenses are generally
offset by fuel revenues through Savannah Electric&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause, these expenses do
not have a significant impact on net income.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power expense </I>&#150; <I>non-affiliates. </I>The slight decrease in the amount of purchased
power from non-affiliates in the first quarter 2005 when compared to the first quarter 2004
resulted from the increase in more economical purchased power from affiliates discussed above.
These transactions do not have a significant impact on earnings, as energy costs are generally
recovered through Savannah Electric&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Maintenance expense. </I>The increase in the first quarter 2005 as compared to the same period in
the prior year is mainly due to scheduled maintenance outages at Plant Kraft and Plant McIntosh and
an increase in distribution expenses primarily related to tree trimming.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other
income (expense), net and income taxes. </I>In the first quarter 2005, other
income increased and income taxes decreased primarily due
to an increase in non-taxable AFUDC equity of $1.1&nbsp;million associated with the Plant McIntosh combined cycle
construction project. See Note 3 to the financial statements under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#150;
Plant McIntosh Construction Project&#148; of Savannah Electric in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional
information. AFUDC equity is expected to substantially decrease
following commercial operation of the project in June 2005; thus
Savannah Electric&#146;s annual effective income tax rate is expected
to be approximately 35%
for 2005. See Note 5 to the financial statements of Savannah Electric
in Item 8 of the Form 10-K and Note (N) to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Dividends on preferred stock. </I>Dividends on preferred stock increased for the first quarter
2005 due to the issuance of 1.8&nbsp;million shares of 6.00% Series&nbsp;Preferred Stock in June&nbsp;2004.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">81
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Savannah Electric&#146;s
future earnings potential. The level of Savannah Electric&#146;s future earnings depends on numerous
factors that affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Savannah Electric&#146;s business of selling electricity. These factors include Savannah Electric&#146;s ability to maintain a
stable regulatory environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stringent environmental standards. Future
earnings in the near term will depend, in part, upon growth in energy sales, which is subject to a
number of factors. These factors include weather, competition, energy conservation practiced by
customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and the rate of economic
growth in Savannah Electric&#146;s service area. For additional information relating to these issues,
see BUSINESS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> -</FONT> The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Savannah Electric in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For additional information, including information on
certain environmental litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS
POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Savannah Electric in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Savannah Electric under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The EPA issued the final Clean Air Interstate Rule on March&nbsp;10, 2005. The rule addresses
sulfur dioxide (SO<SUB>2</SUB>) and nitrogen oxide (NO<SUB>x</SUB>) emissions that contribute to
nonattainment of the eight-hour ozone and fine particulate matter National Ambient Air Quality
Standards. Twenty-eight eastern states, including the State of Georgia, are subject to the fine
particulate and/or the eight-hour ozone requirements set forth within the rule. The rule may
require additional reductions of NO<SUB>x</SUB> and/or SO<SUB>2</SUB> to be achieved by the
installation of additional controls at Savannah Electric&#146;s facilities or through the purchase of
allowances. The impact of this final rule on Savannah Electric will, however, depend on the
development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be determined
at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced the final Clean Air Mercury Rule, selecting a
cap-and-trade approach to be implemented in two phases, 2010 and 2018. The rule sets a permanent
cap on emissions at the 2018 level and provides for an emissions allowance trading market. The
impact of this final rule on Savannah Electric will depend on resolution of legal challenges and
the development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be
determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced plans to extend the deadline for issuance of final rules
addressing Best Available Retrofit Technology standards under its Regional Haze program until June
15, 2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FERC and Georgia PSC Matters</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and
Georgia PSC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Savannah Electric in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to
the financial statements of Savannah Electric under &#147;Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for
measuring generation market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to
assess Southern Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory. Savannah
Electric has authorization from the FERC



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">82
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">to sell power to non-affiliates at market-based prices. Savannah Electric, through SCS as
agent, also has FERC authority to make short-term opportunity sales at market rates. Specific
FERC approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based contract with an affiliate. As
directed by this order, on February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company submitted additional information
related to generation dominance in its retail service territory. Any new market-based rate
transactions in Southern Company&#146;s retail service territory entered into after February&nbsp;27, 2005
will be subject to refund to the level of the default cost-based rates, pending the outcome of
the proceeding. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures are ultimately applied
Savannah Electric may be required to charge cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales in the
Southern Company retail service territory, which may be lower than negotiated market-based
rates. The impact of such sales through March 31, 2005 is not
material to Savannah Electric&#146;s net income. The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in which the final methodology
for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot
be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Retail Rate Case Filing</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On November&nbsp;30, 2004, Savannah Electric filed a traditional one-year rate case with the Georgia PSC
requesting a $23.2&nbsp;million, or 6.7%, increase in retail revenues, effective January&nbsp;1, 2005. The
requested increase is based on a future test year ending December&nbsp;31, 2005 and a proposed retail
return on common equity of 12.5%. As an alternative, Savannah Electric has also included in its
request a three-year rate plan that is based on the same test year and proposed retail return on
common equity.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in retail revenues is being requested to cover Savannah Electric&#146;s investment in
the new Plant McIntosh Combined Cycle Units 10 and 11; increasing operating and maintenance
expenses; and continued investment in generation, transmission, and distribution facilities to
support growth and ensure reliability. Hearings were held in March and April&nbsp;2005 and the Georgia
PSC is expected to issue a final order in May&nbsp;2005, following which the new rates will become
effective in June&nbsp;2005. The final outcome of this matter cannot now be determined. See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and Georgia PSC Matters &#150;
Retail Rate Case Filing&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Savannah Electric
under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#150; 2004 Retail Rate Case Filing&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and
Note (K)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Other Matters</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Effective September&nbsp;30, 2004, Savannah Electric retired Units 4 and 5 at Plant Riverside. The
remaining units at the plant are expected to be retired on May&nbsp;31, 2005. These retirements will
have no material impact on Savannah Electric&#146;s financial statements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Savannah Electric is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary
course of business. In addition, Savannah Electric&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive
governmental regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over
environmental issues and claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, and
citizen enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout the United
States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous
materials have become more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such litigation against Savannah
Electric cannot be predicted at this time; however, management does not anticipate that the
liabilities, if any, arising from such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on
Savannah Electric&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various
contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings potential.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">83
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1
to the financial statements of Savannah Electric in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of
these policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Savannah Electric&#146;s
results of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could
produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements.
Also see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical
Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Savannah Electric in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete
discussion of Savannah Electric&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric
Utility Regulation, Contingent Obligations, and Unbilled Revenues.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123R, Share-Based Payments, was issued in December&nbsp;2004. This statement
requires that compensation cost relating to share-based payment transactions be recognized in
financial statements. That cost will be measured based on the grant date fair value of the equity
or liability instruments issued. In April&nbsp;2005, the SEC amended the compliance dates for FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;123R. For Savannah Electric, this statement is now effective beginning January&nbsp;1,
2006. Although the compensation expense calculation required under the revised statement differs
slightly, the impacts on Savannah Electric&#146;s financial statements are expected to be similar to the
pro forma disclosures included in Note 1 to the financial statements of Savannah Electric under
&#147;Stock Options&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and in Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements
herein.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;47 (FIN 47), Accounting for Conditional Asset Retirement Obligations,
was issued in March&nbsp;2005. This interpretation requires that asset retirement obligations be
recorded when a legal obligation exists even though the timing and/or the method of settlement are
conditional on a future event. For Savannah Electric, FIN 47 is effective no later than December
31, 2005. Savannah Electric is currently assessing the impact of FIN 47 on its balance sheet;
however, adoption is not currently expected to have a material impact on Savannah Electric&#146;s income
statement.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued Staff Position No.&nbsp;109-1 (FSP 109-1), Application of FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;109, Accounting for Income Taxes, to the Tax Deduction on Qualified Production
Activities provided by the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004, which requires that the generation
deduction for utilities be accounted for as a special tax deduction rather than as a tax rate
reduction. Savannah Electric adopted FSP 109-1 in the first quarter of 2005 with no material
impact on its financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Net cash flow provided from operating activities totaled $(2.1) million for the first quarter 2005,
compared to $13.6&nbsp;million for the first quarter 2004. The $15.7&nbsp;million decrease in 2005 resulted
primarily from higher fuel costs. Those costs are recoverable in future periods and are reflected
on the balance sheets as under recovered regulatory clause revenues. Major changes in Savannah
Electric&#146;s financial condition during the first three months of 2005 included the addition of
approximately $15.9&nbsp;million to utility plant, which includes the Plant McIntosh combined cycle
construction project. The funds for these additions and other capital requirements



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">84
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">were derived primarily from short-term debt. See Savannah Electric&#146;s Condensed Statements of Cash
Flows herein for further details.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151;  &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Savannah Electric in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Savannah Electric&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, lease
obligations, purchase commitments, and trust funding requirements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from
sources similar to those used in the past including both internal and external funds. The amount,
type, and timing of any future financings &#151; if needed &#151; will depend upon maintenance of adequate
earnings, regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions, and other factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Savannah
Electric in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, Savannah Electric had at March&nbsp;31, 2005
approximately $2.6&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and $80&nbsp;million of unused committed credit
arrangements with banks, of which $70&nbsp;million expires in 2005, and $10&nbsp;million expires in 2007. Of
the unused credit arrangements expiring in 2005, $40&nbsp;million include two-year term loan options
executable at the expiration date. The credit arrangements provide liquidity support to some of
Savannah Electric&#146;s obligations with respect to its variable rate debt and its commercial paper.
Savannah Electric expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to expiration. Savannah
Electric may also meet short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to
issue and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit
of Savannah Electric and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At March&nbsp;31, 2005, Savannah Electric
had $32.1&nbsp;million of outstanding commercial paper and $8.0&nbsp;million of outstanding extendible
commercial notes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in
payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. Savannah Electric is
party to certain derivatives agreements that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in
the event of a credit rating change to below investment grade. These agreements are primarily for natural gas price and
interest rate risk management activities. At March&nbsp;31, 2005, Savannah Electric had no exposure
under these contracts.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed
materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2004 reporting period. In addition, Savannah Electric is
not aware of any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near
term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Savannah Electric has limited exposure to market
volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate
residual risks relative to movements in electricity prices, Savannah Electric enters into
fixed-price contracts for the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity
market and, to a lesser extent, similar contracts for gas and oil purchases. Savannah Electric has
also implemented a retail fuel hedging program at the instruction of the Georgia PSC.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">85
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Savannah Electric in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements of Savannah Electric under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K, and Note
(F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric did not issue or redeem any long-term securities during the first quarter of
2005. In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements and
contractual obligations, Savannah Electric plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program
to retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if market
conditions permit.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the first quarter of 2005, Savannah Electric entered into a forward starting interest rate
swap in order to mitigate its exposure to unfavorable changes in interest rates related to a series
of senior notes Savannah Electric anticipates to issue in 2006. See Note (F)&nbsp;to the Condensed
Financial Statements herein for additional information.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">86
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY</B><BR>

<DIV align="center">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">91
</DIV>


<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY</B>


<DIV align="left">
<A name="110"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FIRST QUARTER 2005 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2004



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Power constructs, owns, and manages Southern Company&#146;s competitive generation assets
and sells electricity at market-based rates in the Super Southeast wholesale market. Southern
Power continues to focus on executing its regional strategy in the Super Southeast in 2005.
However, Southern Power continues to face challenges related to market power issues at the
federal regulatory level, specifically the ability to charge market-based rates.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To evaluate operating results and to ensure Southern Power&#146;s ability to meet its
contractual commitments to customers, Southern Power focuses on two key performance indicators.
These indicators consist of plant availability and peak season equivalent forced outage rate
(EFOR). Plant availability shows the percentage of time during the year that Southern Power&#146;s
generating units are available to be called upon to generate (the higher the better), whereas
the EFOR more narrowly defines the hours during peak demand times when Southern Power&#146;s
generating units are not available due to forced outages (the lower the better). For additional
information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW &#150; &#147;Key
Performance Indicators&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Power&#146;s net income for first quarter 2005 was $23.1&nbsp;million compared to $27.2&nbsp;million for
the corresponding period of 2004. The decrease in first quarter 2005 earnings of $4.1&nbsp;million, or
15.1%, was primarily the result of ceasing the capitalization of interest on construction.
Capitalization of construction interest ended with the sale of Plant McIntosh Units 10 and 11 to
Georgia Power and Savannah Electric in May&nbsp;2004 and the cessation of construction activities at
Plant Franklin Unit 3 in August&nbsp;2004. For further information, see Note 2 to the financial
statements of Southern Power under &#147;Plant Franklin Unit 3 Construction Project&#148; and &#147;Plant McIntosh
Construction Project&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. Reductions in operating revenues at Plant Harris
Unit 2 and Plant Franklin 2 caused by the shift from market sales of this capacity to sales to
affiliates under PPAs in June&nbsp;2004 were largely offset by reductions in purchased power expense.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the following:

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="50%">
